\newsiamremark

remarkRemark \newsiamremarkhypothesisHypothesis \newsiamthmclaimClaim \headersConvergence Analysis of DYS via SRGLee, Yi, and Ryu \externaldocument[][nocite]ex_supplement

Convergence Analyses of Davis–Yin Splitting via Scaled Relative Graphs

Jongmin Lee†‡    Soheun Yi§‡    Ernest K. Ryu†
Abstract

Davis–Yin splitting (DYS) has found a wide range of applications in optimization, but its linear rates of convergence have not been studied extensively. The scaled relative graph (SRG) simplifies the convergence analysis of operator splitting methods by mapping the action of the operator to the complex plane, but the prior SRG theory did not fully apply to the DYS operator. In this work, we formalize an SRG theory for the DYS operator and use it to obtain tighter contraction factors.

keywords:
Convex optimization, Splitting methods, Monotone operators, Euclidean geometry
00footnotetext: ††\dagger†Department of Mathematical Sciences, Seoul National University.00footnotetext: ‡‡\ddagger‡Equal contribution.00footnotetext: §§\S§Department of Statistics and Data Science, Carnegie Mellon University.
{MSCcodes}

68Q25, 68R10, 68U05

1 Introduction

The Davis–Yin splitting (DYS) operator [18] encodes solutions of the three-operator monotone inclusion problem

findx∈ℋ0∈(++)x,\displaystyle\underset{x\in{\mathcal{H}}}{\text{find}}\quad 0\in({\varbbA}+{% \varbbB}+{\varbbC})x,start_UNDERACCENT italic_x ∈ caligraphic_H end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG find end_ARG 0 ∈ ( + + ) italic_x ,

where ℋℋ{\mathcal{H}}caligraphic_H is a real Hilbert space, and are monotone, and is cocoercive, as fixed-points of the operator

=−+α(2−α−α)αα,{\varbbT}={\varbbI}-{}_{\alpha{\varbbB}}+{}_{\alpha{\varbbA}}(2{}_{\alpha{% \varbbB}}-{\varbbI}-\alpha{\varbbC}{}_{\alpha{\varbbB}}),= - start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT + start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT ( 2 start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT - - italic_α start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT ) ,

where α>0𝛼0\alpha>0italic_α > 0 and α and α are the resolvents of and . DYS generalizes the forward-backward splitting (FBS) and Douglas–Rachford splitting (DRS) operators, and it has found a wide range of applications [48, 46, 7, 44, 47, 24] in optimization. However, linear convergence rates of DYS iterations have not been studied extensively.

On the other hand, the recently proposed scaled relative graph (SRG) [38] allows one to analyze the convergence of operator splitting methods by mapping the action of a multi-valued nonlinear operator to the extended complex plane, analogous to how the spectrum maps the action of a linear operator to the complex plane. Prior work used the SRG to analyze rates of convergence for FBS and DRS [38], but the prior SRG theory did not fully apply to the DYS operator.

In this paper, we analyze convergence rates of DYS iterations using the SRG. First, we extend the SRG theory to accommodate the DYS operator. We then establish linear rates of convergence of DYS by bounding the maximum modulus of the SRG on the complex plane. We furthermore provide a new result on averagedness coefficients of DYS.

1.1 Prior Works

Splitting methods for monotone inclusion problems is a powerful framework encompassing a wide range of convex optimization algorithms [2, 37, 40]. Classical splitting methods such as forward-backward splitting (FBS) [6, 30, 3], Douglas–Rachford splitting (DRS) [32, 19, 28], and alternating directions method of multipliers (ADMM) [21, 22], a derived splitting algorithm, have had an enormous range of applications. As a splitting scheme unifying FBS and DRS, Generalized forward-backward splitting (GFBS) [36] was first proposed, and Forward-Douglas–Rachford splitting (FDRS) [5] was then presented as an extension of GFBS. In 2017, Davis and Yin proposed what we call the Davis-Yin splitting (DYS) as a complete unification of FBS and DRS [18]. This breakthrough has found a wide range of new applications [48, 46, 7, 44, 47, 24] and many variants of DYS such as stochastic DYS [49, 51, 8, 50, 34], inexact DYS [52], adaptive DYS [35], inertial DYS [15], and primal-dual DYS[41] have been proposed.

However, the study of linear convergence rates of DYS has been limited. Bredies, Chenchene, Lorenz, and Naldi studied the convergence of DYS under a wider range of stepsizes [4] and Aragón-Artacho and Torregrosa-Belén also proved the convergence of the DYS iteration over a wider range of stepsizes [1]. Dao and Phan analyzed a modified version of DYS iterations [16], and Pedregosa analyzed sublinear convergence rates of DYS iterations [33], but they did not analyze linear rates of convergence. Condat and Richtárik analyzed linear convergence rates of a randomized version of Primal-Dual Davis–Yin (PDDY) [14]. Ryu, Taylor, Bergeling, and Giselsson [39] and Wang, Fazlyab, Chen, and Preciado [45] formulated the problem of computing tight contraction factors as SDPs using the performance estimation problem (PEP) and integral quadratic constraint (IQC) approaches, but these are numerical results, not analytic convergence proofs in the classical sense. To the best of our knowledge, the only prior works providing analytic linear convergence rates of DYS iterations are the arXiv version of the original DYS paper [18] and [14]. The latter work [14] considers randomized updates, which makes the setup distinct from ours.

On the other hand, the theory of scaled relative graph (SRG) by Ryu, Hannah, and Yin [38] allows one to analyze the convergence of operator splitting methods by mapping the action of a multi-valued nonlinear operator to the extended complex plane, analogous to how the spectrum maps the action of a linear operator to the complex plane. Follow-up work has extended the theory and applied it to analyze nonlinear operators: Huang, Ryu, and Yin characterized the SRG of normal matrices [25], Pates further characterized the SRG of linear operators using the Toeplitz–Hausdorff theorem [31], and Huang, Ryu, and Yin [26] established the tightness of the averagedness coefficient of the composition of averaged operators [29] and the DYS operator [18]. SRG has also found applications in control theory: Chaffey, Forni, and Rodolphe utilized the SRG to analyze input-output properties of feedback systems [11, 10], and Chaffey and Sepulchre furthermore used it as an experimental tool to determine properties of a given model[13, 9, 12].

1.2 Contribution and organization

Section 2 presents our first major contribution, formalizing an SRG theory for the DYS operator. This result reduces the problem of analyzing the DYS operator into bounding the maximum modulus of a subset of the complex plane. Section 3 presents our second major contribution, analyzing contraction factors of the DYS operator. These factors are tighter than those shown in [18] and are, to the best of our knowledge, the best known factors. Finally, Section 4 presents a minor contribution, a tight averagedness coefficient of the DYS operator under the assumption of strong monotonicity of or and Lipschitzness of . This is, to the best of our knowledge, the first averagedness result of DYS without cocoercivity of .

1.3 Preliminaries

Write ℋℋ{\mathcal{H}}caligraphic_H for a real Hilbert space with inner product ⟨⋅,⋅⟩⋅⋅\langle\cdot,\cdot\rangle⟨ ⋅ , ⋅ ⟩ and norm ∥⋅∥delimited-∥∥⋅\lVert\cdot\rVert∥ ⋅ ∥. Write ℂ¯=ℂ∪{∞}¯ℂℂ\overline{\mathbb{C}}=\mathbb{C}\cup\{\infty\}over¯ start_ARG blackboard_C end_ARG = blackboard_C ∪ { ∞ } to denote the extended complex plane, and define 1/0=∞101/0=\infty1 / 0 = ∞ and 1/∞=0101/\infty=01 / ∞ = 0 in ℂ¯¯ℂ\overline{\mathbb{C}}over¯ start_ARG blackboard_C end_ARG. We use Minkowski-type set notations: for α∈ℂ𝛼ℂ\alpha\in\mathbb{C}italic_α ∈ blackboard_C and W,Z⊆ℂ𝑊𝑍ℂW,Z\subseteq\mathbb{C}italic_W , italic_Z ⊆ blackboard_C, write

W⁢α=α⁢W={α⁢w|w∈W},W+α=α+W={α+w|w∈W},formulae-sequence𝑊𝛼𝛼𝑊conditional-set𝛼𝑤𝑤𝑊𝑊𝛼𝛼𝑊conditional-set𝛼𝑤𝑤𝑊\displaystyle W\alpha=\alpha W=\{\alpha w\,|\,w\in W\},\quad W+\alpha=\alpha+W% =\{\alpha+w\,|\,w\in W\},italic_W italic_α = italic_α italic_W = { italic_α italic_w | italic_w ∈ italic_W } , italic_W + italic_α = italic_α + italic_W = { italic_α + italic_w | italic_w ∈ italic_W } ,

and

W+Z={w+z|w∈W,z∈Z},W⁢Z={w⁢z|w∈W,z∈Z}.formulae-sequence𝑊𝑍conditional-set𝑤𝑧formulae-sequence𝑤𝑊𝑧𝑍𝑊𝑍conditional-set𝑤𝑧formulae-sequence𝑤𝑊𝑧𝑍W+Z=\{w+z\,|\,w\in W,z\in Z\},\quad WZ=\left\{wz\,|\,w\in W,\,z\in Z\right\}.italic_W + italic_Z = { italic_w + italic_z | italic_w ∈ italic_W , italic_z ∈ italic_Z } , italic_W italic_Z = { italic_w italic_z | italic_w ∈ italic_W , italic_z ∈ italic_Z } .

For W⊂ℂ𝑊ℂW\subset\mathbb{C}italic_W ⊂ blackboard_C, write

|W|={|w||w∈W},𝑊conditional-set𝑤𝑤𝑊\lvert W\rvert=\left\{\lvert w\rvert\,|\,w\in W\right\},| italic_W | = { | italic_w | | italic_w ∈ italic_W } ,

where |w|𝑤\lvert w\rvert| italic_w | is absolute value (modulus) of a complex number w𝑤witalic_w. To clarify, |W|𝑊\lvert W\rvert| italic_W | does not refer to the cardinality of W𝑊Witalic_W. For W⊂ℂ¯𝑊¯ℂW\subset\overline{\mathbb{C}}italic_W ⊂ over¯ start_ARG blackboard_C end_ARG, write

W−1={w−1|w∈W}.superscript𝑊1conditional-setsuperscript𝑤1𝑤𝑊\quad W^{-1}=\left\{w^{-1}\,|\,w\in W\right\}.italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = { italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_w ∈ italic_W } .

For z∈ℂ𝑧ℂz\in\mathbb{C}italic_z ∈ blackboard_C, write Re⁡zRe𝑧\operatorname{Re}zroman_Re italic_z and Im⁡zIm𝑧\operatorname{Im}zroman_Im italic_z for the real and imaginary part of z𝑧zitalic_z, respectively, and arg⁡z𝑧\arg zroman_arg italic_z for the argument of z𝑧zitalic_z that lies within (−π,π]𝜋𝜋(-\pi,\pi]( - italic_π , italic_π ].

Geometry

Given any x,y∈ℋ𝑥𝑦ℋx,y\in{\mathcal{H}}italic_x , italic_y ∈ caligraphic_H, define

∠⁢(x,y)={arccos⁡(⟨x,y⟩∥x∥⁢∥y∥) if ⁢x≠0,y≠00 otherwise∠𝑥𝑦cases𝑥𝑦delimited-∥∥𝑥delimited-∥∥𝑦formulae-sequence if 𝑥0𝑦00 otherwise\displaystyle\angle(x,y)=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}\arccos\left({\tfrac{% \langle x,y\rangle}{\lVert x\rVert\lVert y\rVert}}\right)&\text{ if }x\neq 0,% \,y\neq 0\\ 0&\text{ otherwise}\end{array}\right.∠ ( italic_x , italic_y ) = { start_ARRAY start_ROW start_CELL roman_arccos ( divide start_ARG ⟨ italic_x , italic_y ⟩ end_ARG start_ARG ∥ italic_x ∥ ∥ italic_y ∥ end_ARG ) end_CELL start_CELL if italic_x ≠ 0 , italic_y ≠ 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL otherwise end_CELL end_ROW end_ARRAY

to be the angle between x𝑥xitalic_x and y𝑦yitalic_y. Note that ∠⁢(x,y)∈[0,π]∠𝑥𝑦0𝜋\angle(x,y)\in[0,\pi]∠ ( italic_x , italic_y ) ∈ [ 0 , italic_π ]. The following spherical triangle inequality is the analog of the triangle inequality on spheres.

Fact 1 (Fact 17 [38]).

Let ℋℋ{\mathcal{H}}caligraphic_H be a real Hilbert space. Then,

|∠⁢(x,y)−∠⁢(y,u)|≤∠⁢(x,u)≤∠⁢(x,y)+∠⁢(y,u),∀x,y,u∈ℋ.formulae-sequence∠𝑥𝑦∠𝑦𝑢∠𝑥𝑢∠𝑥𝑦∠𝑦𝑢for-all𝑥𝑦𝑢ℋ\left|\angle(x,y)-\angle(y,u)\right|\leq\angle(x,u)\leq\angle(x,y)+\angle(y,u)% ,\qquad\forall\,x,y,u\in{\mathcal{H}}.| ∠ ( italic_x , italic_y ) - ∠ ( italic_y , italic_u ) | ≤ ∠ ( italic_x , italic_u ) ≤ ∠ ( italic_x , italic_y ) + ∠ ( italic_y , italic_u ) , ∀ italic_x , italic_y , italic_u ∈ caligraphic_H .

We define notations for disks and circles on the complex plane. For z∈ℂ𝑧ℂz\in\mathbb{C}italic_z ∈ blackboard_C and r∈(0,∞)𝑟0r\in(0,\infty)italic_r ∈ ( 0 , ∞ ), define

Circ⁢(z,r)={w∈ℂ||w−z|=r},Disk⁢(z,r)={w∈ℂ||w−z|≤r}.formulae-sequenceCirc𝑧𝑟conditional-set𝑤ℂ𝑤𝑧𝑟Disk𝑧𝑟conditional-set𝑤ℂ𝑤𝑧𝑟{\mathrm{Circ}}(z,r)=\{w\in\mathbb{C}\,|\,\lvert w-z\rvert=r\},\qquad{\mathrm{% Disk}}(z,r)=\{w\in\mathbb{C}\,|\,\lvert w-z\rvert\leq r\}.roman_Circ ( italic_z , italic_r ) = { italic_w ∈ blackboard_C | | italic_w - italic_z | = italic_r } , roman_Disk ( italic_z , italic_r ) = { italic_w ∈ blackboard_C | | italic_w - italic_z | ≤ italic_r } .
Multi-valued operators

In general, we follow standard convex operator theoretical notations as in [2, 40]. Write :ℋ⇉ℋ:absent⇉ℋℋ{\varbbA}\colon{\mathcal{H}}\rightrightarrows{\mathcal{H}}: caligraphic_H ⇉ caligraphic_H to denote that is a multi-valued operator. Define dom={x∈ℋ|x≠∅}domconditional-set𝑥ℋ𝑥\mathrm{dom}\,{\varbbA}=\left\{x\in{\mathcal{H}}\,|\,{\varbbA}x\neq\emptyset\right\}roman_dom = { italic_x ∈ caligraphic_H | italic_x ≠ ∅ }. If all outputs of are singletons or the empty set, we say is single-valued. In this case, we identify with the function from domdom\mathrm{dom}\,{\varbbA}roman_dom to ℋℋ{\mathcal{H}}caligraphic_H. Define the graph of an operator as

graph⁢()={(x,u)∈ℋ×ℋ|u∈x}.graphconditional-set𝑥𝑢ℋℋ𝑢𝑥\mathrm{graph}({\varbbA})=\{(x,u)\in{\mathcal{H}}\times{\mathcal{H}}\,|\,u\in{% \varbbA}x\}.roman_graph ( ) = { ( italic_x , italic_u ) ∈ caligraphic_H × caligraphic_H | italic_u ∈ italic_x } .

For notational simplicity, we often do not distinguish an operator from its graph and, for example, write (x,u)∈𝑥𝑢absent(x,u)\in{\varbbA}( italic_x , italic_u ) ∈ to mean u∈x𝑢𝑥u\in{\varbbA}xitalic_u ∈ italic_x. Define the inverse of as

=−1{(u,x)|(x,u)∈},{}^{-1}=\{(u,x)\,|\,(x,u)\in{\varbbA}\},start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT = { ( italic_u , italic_x ) | ( italic_x , italic_u ) ∈ } ,

scalar multiplication with an operator as

α={(x,αu)|(x,u)∈},\alpha{\varbbA}=\{(x,\alpha u)\,|\,(x,u)\in{\varbbA}\},italic_α = { ( italic_x , italic_α italic_u ) | ( italic_x , italic_u ) ∈ } ,

the identity operator as

={(x,x)|x∈ℋ},absentconditional-set𝑥𝑥𝑥ℋ{\varbbI}=\{(x,x)\,|\,x\in{\mathcal{H}}\},= { ( italic_x , italic_x ) | italic_x ∈ caligraphic_H } ,

and

+α=α+={(x,αx+u)|(x,u)∈}{\varbbA}+\alpha{\varbbI}=\alpha{\varbbI}+{\varbbA}=\{(x,\alpha x+u)\,|\,(x,u)% \in{\varbbA}\}+ italic_α = italic_α + = { ( italic_x , italic_α italic_x + italic_u ) | ( italic_x , italic_u ) ∈ }

for any α∈ℝ𝛼ℝ\alpha\in\mathbb{R}italic_α ∈ blackboard_R. Define the resolvent of with stepsize α>0𝛼0\alpha>0italic_α > 0 as

=α(+α)−1.{}_{\alpha{\varbbA}}=({\varbbI}+\alpha{\varbbA})^{-1}.start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT = ( + italic_α ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

Define addition and composition of operators :ℋ⇉ℋ:absent⇉ℋℋ{\varbbA}\colon{\mathcal{H}}\rightrightarrows{\mathcal{H}}: caligraphic_H ⇉ caligraphic_H and :ℋ⇉ℋ:absent⇉ℋℋ{\varbbB}\colon{\mathcal{H}}\rightrightarrows{\mathcal{H}}: caligraphic_H ⇉ caligraphic_H as

+\displaystyle{\varbbA}+{\varbbB}+ ={(x,u+v)|(x,u)∈,(x,v)∈},\displaystyle=\left\{(x,u+v)\,|\,(x,u)\in{\varbbA},(x,v)\in{\varbbB}\right\},= { ( italic_x , italic_u + italic_v ) | ( italic_x , italic_u ) ∈ , ( italic_x , italic_v ) ∈ } ,
={(x,s)|∃usuch that(x,u)∈,(u,s)∈}.\displaystyle=\left\{(x,s)\,|\,\exists\,u\;\text{such that}\;(x,u)\in{\varbbB}% ,(u,s)\in{\varbbA}\right\}.= { ( italic_x , italic_s ) | ∃ italic_u such that ( italic_x , italic_u ) ∈ , ( italic_u , italic_s ) ∈ } .

We call 𝒜𝒜{\mathcal{A}}caligraphic_A a class of operators if it is a set of operators. Operators in a same class need not be defined on the same Hilbert space. For an operator :ℋ⇉ℋ:absent⇉ℋℋ{\varbbA}\colon{\mathcal{H}}\rightrightarrows{\mathcal{H}}: caligraphic_H ⇉ caligraphic_H and an operator class ℬℬ{\mathcal{B}}caligraphic_B, we define sum and product of them as

+ℬℬ\displaystyle{\varbbA}+{\mathcal{B}}+ caligraphic_B ={+|∈ℬ,:ℋ⇉ℋ},\displaystyle=\{{\varbbA}+{\varbbB}\,|\,{\varbbB}\in{\mathcal{B}},{\varbbB}% \colon{\mathcal{H}}\rightrightarrows{\mathcal{H}}\},= { + | ∈ caligraphic_B , : caligraphic_H ⇉ caligraphic_H } ,
ℬℬ\displaystyle{\varbbA}{\mathcal{B}}caligraphic_B ={|∈ℬ,:ℋ⇉ℋ}\displaystyle=\{{\varbbA}{\varbbB}\,|\,{\varbbB}\in{\mathcal{B}},{\varbbB}% \colon{\mathcal{H}}\rightrightarrows{\mathcal{H}}\}= { | ∈ caligraphic_B , : caligraphic_H ⇉ caligraphic_H }

Note that we restrict operands to be defined on the same domain Hilbert space ℋℋ{\mathcal{H}}caligraphic_H. For an operator class 𝒜𝒜{\mathcal{A}}caligraphic_A and :ℋ⇉ℋ:absent⇉ℋℋ{\varbbB}\colon{\mathcal{H}}\rightrightarrows{\mathcal{H}}: caligraphic_H ⇉ caligraphic_H, define 𝒜+limit-from𝒜{\mathcal{A}}+{\varbbB}caligraphic_A + and 𝒜𝒜{\mathcal{A}}{\varbbB}caligraphic_A in the same way. We define sum of classes of operators 𝒜𝒜{\mathcal{A}}caligraphic_A and ℬℬ{\mathcal{B}}caligraphic_B as

𝒜+ℬ={+|\displaystyle{\mathcal{A}}+{\mathcal{B}}=\{{\varbbA}+{\varbbB}\,|\,caligraphic_A + caligraphic_B = { + | ∈𝒜,∈ℬ,:ℋ⇉ℋ,:ℋ⇉ℋ,\displaystyle{\varbbA}\in{\mathcal{A}},\,{\varbbB}\in{\mathcal{B}},{\varbbA}% \colon{\mathcal{H}}\rightrightarrows{\mathcal{H}},\,{\varbbB}\colon{\mathcal{H% }}\rightrightarrows{\mathcal{H}},∈ caligraphic_A , ∈ caligraphic_B , : caligraphic_H ⇉ caligraphic_H , : caligraphic_H ⇉ caligraphic_H ,
ℋ is a Hilbert space}.\displaystyle{\mathcal{H}}\text{ is a Hilbert space}\}.caligraphic_H is a Hilbert space } .

We define 𝒜⁢ℬ𝒜ℬ{\mathcal{A}}{\mathcal{B}}caligraphic_A caligraphic_B similarly. For any α∈ℝ𝛼ℝ\alpha\in\mathbb{R}italic_α ∈ blackboard_R, define

α𝒜={α|∈𝒜}\alpha{\mathcal{A}}=\{\alpha{\varbbA}\,|\,{\varbbA}\in{\mathcal{A}}\}italic_α caligraphic_A = { italic_α | ∈ caligraphic_A }

and

𝒜+α=α+𝒜={α+|∈𝒜}.{\mathcal{A}}+\alpha{\varbbI}=\alpha{\varbbI}+{\mathcal{A}}=\{\alpha{\varbbI}+% {\varbbA}\,|\,{\varbbA}\in{\mathcal{A}}\}.caligraphic_A + italic_α = italic_α + caligraphic_A = { italic_α + | ∈ caligraphic_A } .

Define

𝒜−1={|−1∈𝒜}{\mathcal{A}}^{-1}=\{{}^{-1}\,|\,{\varbbA}\in{\mathcal{A}}\}caligraphic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = { start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT | ∈ caligraphic_A }

and =α⁢𝒜(+α𝒜)−1{}_{\alpha{\mathcal{A}}}=({\varbbI}+\alpha{\mathcal{A}})^{-1}start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_α caligraphic_A end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT = ( + italic_α caligraphic_A ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for α>0𝛼0\alpha>0italic_α > 0.

We now define some special operator classes. Define the class of monotone operators as

ℳ={:ℋ⇉ℋ|⟨x−y,u−v⟩≥0,∀u∈x,v∈y,ℋ is a Hilbert space}.{\mathcal{M}}=\{{\varbbA}\colon{\mathcal{H}}\rightrightarrows{\mathcal{H}}\,|% \,\langle x-y,u-v\rangle\geq 0,\forall\,u\in{\varbbA}x,v\in{\varbbA}y,\,{% \mathcal{H}}\text{ is a Hilbert space}\}.caligraphic_M = { : caligraphic_H ⇉ caligraphic_H | ⟨ italic_x - italic_y , italic_u - italic_v ⟩ ≥ 0 , ∀ italic_u ∈ italic_x , italic_v ∈ italic_y , caligraphic_H is a Hilbert space } .

For μ∈(0,∞)𝜇0\mu\in(0,\infty)italic_μ ∈ ( 0 , ∞ ), define the class of μ𝜇\muitalic_μ-strongly monotone operators as

ℳμ={:ℋ⇉ℋ|\displaystyle{\mathcal{M}}_{\mu}=\{{\varbbA}\colon{\mathcal{H}}% \rightrightarrows{\mathcal{H}}\,|\,caligraphic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_μ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { : caligraphic_H ⇉ caligraphic_H | ⟨x−y,u−v⟩≥μ⁢∥x−y∥2,∀u∈x,v∈y,formulae-sequence𝑥𝑦𝑢𝑣𝜇superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑥𝑦2formulae-sequencefor-all𝑢𝑥𝑣𝑦\displaystyle\langle x-y,u-v\rangle\geq\mu\lVert x-y\rVert^{2},\,\forall\,u\in% {\varbbA}x,v\in{\varbbA}y,⟨ italic_x - italic_y , italic_u - italic_v ⟩ ≥ italic_μ ∥ italic_x - italic_y ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ∀ italic_u ∈ italic_x , italic_v ∈ italic_y ,
ℋ is a Hilbert space}.\displaystyle{\mathcal{H}}\text{ is a Hilbert space}\}.caligraphic_H is a Hilbert space } .

For L∈(0,∞)𝐿0L\in(0,\infty)italic_L ∈ ( 0 , ∞ ), define the class of L𝐿Litalic_L-Lipschitz operators as

ℒL={:dom→ℋ|\displaystyle{\mathcal{L}}_{L}=\{{\varbbA}\colon\mathrm{dom}\,{\varbbA}\to{% \mathcal{H}}\,|\,caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { : roman_dom → caligraphic_H | ∥u−v∥2≤L2⁢∥x−y∥2,∀u∈x,v∈y,formulae-sequencesuperscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑢𝑣2superscript𝐿2superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑥𝑦2formulae-sequencefor-all𝑢𝑥𝑣𝑦\displaystyle\lVert u-v\rVert^{2}\leq L^{2}\lVert x-y\rVert^{2},\forall\,u\in{% \varbbA}x,v\in{\varbbA}y,∥ italic_u - italic_v ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ italic_x - italic_y ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ∀ italic_u ∈ italic_x , italic_v ∈ italic_y ,
dom⊆ℋ,ℋ is a Hilbert space}.\displaystyle\mathrm{dom}\,{\varbbA}\subseteq{\mathcal{H}},\,{\mathcal{H}}% \text{ is a Hilbert space}\}.roman_dom ⊆ caligraphic_H , caligraphic_H is a Hilbert space } .

For β∈(0,∞)𝛽0\beta\in(0,\infty)italic_β ∈ ( 0 , ∞ ), define the class of β𝛽\betaitalic_β-cocoercive operators as

𝒞β={:dom→ℋ|\displaystyle{\mathcal{C}}_{\beta}=\{{\varbbA}\colon\mathrm{dom}\,{\varbbA}\to% {\mathcal{H}}\,|\,caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_β end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { : roman_dom → caligraphic_H | ⟨x−y,u−v⟩≥β⁢∥u−v∥2,∀u∈x,v∈y,formulae-sequence𝑥𝑦𝑢𝑣𝛽superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑢𝑣2formulae-sequencefor-all𝑢𝑥𝑣𝑦\displaystyle\langle x-y,u-v\rangle\geq\beta\lVert u-v\rVert^{2},\forall\,u\in% {\varbbA}x,v\in{\varbbA}y,⟨ italic_x - italic_y , italic_u - italic_v ⟩ ≥ italic_β ∥ italic_u - italic_v ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ∀ italic_u ∈ italic_x , italic_v ∈ italic_y ,
dom⊆ℋ,ℋ is a Hilbert space}.\displaystyle\mathrm{dom}\,{\varbbA}\subseteq{\mathcal{H}},\,{\mathcal{H}}% \text{ is a Hilbert space}\}.roman_dom ⊆ caligraphic_H , caligraphic_H is a Hilbert space } .

For θ∈(0,1)𝜃01\theta\in(0,1)italic_θ ∈ ( 0 , 1 ), define the class of θ𝜃\thetaitalic_θ-averaged operators as

𝒩θ=(1−θ)+θ⁢ℒ1.subscript𝒩𝜃1𝜃𝜃subscriptℒ1{\mathcal{N}}_{\theta}=(1-\theta){\varbbI}+\theta{\mathcal{L}}_{1}.caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( 1 - italic_θ ) + italic_θ caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

Note that we automatically identify Lipschitz and cocoercive operators, as well as resolvents of monotone operators, as singled-value functions since they are necessarily single-valued. For notational convenience, we write

ℳ0=𝒞0=ℳ,ℒ∞={:ℋ⇉ℋ|ℋ is a Hilbert space}.{\mathcal{M}}_{0}={\mathcal{C}}_{0}={\mathcal{M}},\quad{\mathcal{L}}_{\infty}=% \left\{{\varbbA}\colon{\mathcal{H}}\rightrightarrows{\mathcal{H}}\,|\,{% \mathcal{H}}\text{ is a Hilbert space}\right\}.caligraphic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = caligraphic_M , caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { : caligraphic_H ⇉ caligraphic_H | caligraphic_H is a Hilbert space } .

To clarify,

ℳ0≠⋃μ>0ℳμ,𝒞0≠⋃β>0𝒞β,ℒ∞≠⋃L<∞ℒL.formulae-sequencesubscriptℳ0subscript𝜇0subscriptℳ𝜇formulae-sequencesubscript𝒞0subscript𝛽0subscript𝒞𝛽subscriptℒsubscript𝐿subscriptℒ𝐿{\mathcal{M}}_{0}\neq\bigcup_{\mu>0}{\mathcal{M}}_{\mu},\quad{\mathcal{C}}_{0}% \neq\bigcup_{\beta>0}{\mathcal{C}}_{\beta},\quad{\mathcal{L}}_{\infty}\neq% \bigcup_{L<\infty}{\mathcal{L}}_{L}.caligraphic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≠ ⋃ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_μ > 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_μ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≠ ⋃ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_β > 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_β end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≠ ⋃ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L < ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .
Scaled relative graphs

Define the SRG of an operator :ℋ⇉ℋ:absent⇉ℋℋ{\varbbA}\colon{\mathcal{H}}\rightrightarrows{\mathcal{H}}: caligraphic_H ⇉ caligraphic_H as

𝒢⁢()𝒢\displaystyle\mathcal{G}({\varbbA})caligraphic_G ( ) ={‖u−v‖‖x−y‖⁢exp⁡[±i⁢∠⁢(u−v,x−y)]|u∈x,v∈y,x≠y}absentconditional-setnorm𝑢𝑣norm𝑥𝑦plus-or-minus𝑖∠𝑢𝑣𝑥𝑦formulae-sequence𝑢𝑥formulae-sequence𝑣𝑦𝑥𝑦\displaystyle=\left\{\frac{\|u-v\|}{\|x-y\|}\exp\left[\pm i\angle(u-v,x-y)% \right]\,\Big{|}\,u\in{\varbbA}x,\,v\in{\varbbA}y,\,x\neq y\right\}= { divide start_ARG ∥ italic_u - italic_v ∥ end_ARG start_ARG ∥ italic_x - italic_y ∥ end_ARG roman_exp [ ± italic_i ∠ ( italic_u - italic_v , italic_x - italic_y ) ] | italic_u ∈ italic_x , italic_v ∈ italic_y , italic_x ≠ italic_y }
(∪{∞}⁢ if is not single-valued). if is not single-valued\displaystyle\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\bigg{(}% \cup\{\infty\}\text{ if ${\varbbA}$ is not single-valued}\bigg{)}.( ∪ { ∞ } if is not single-valued ) .

SRG depicts a change in output relative to the change in input of operators using complex numbers, analogous to how eigenvalues capture essential information about the action of linear operators. We define the SRG of a class of operators 𝒜𝒜{\mathcal{A}}caligraphic_A as

𝒢⁢(𝒜)=⋃∈𝒜𝒢⁢().𝒢𝒜subscriptabsent𝒜𝒢\mathcal{G}({\mathcal{A}})=\bigcup_{{\varbbA}\in{\mathcal{A}}}\mathcal{G}({% \varbbA}).caligraphic_G ( caligraphic_A ) = ⋃ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_G ( ) .
Fact 2 (Proposition 1 [38]).

Let μ𝜇\muitalic_μ,β𝛽\betaitalic_β,L∈(0,∞)𝐿0L\in(0,\infty)italic_L ∈ ( 0 , ∞ ) and θ∈(0,1)𝜃01\theta\in(0,1)italic_θ ∈ ( 0 , 1 ). The SRGs of ℒLsubscriptℒ𝐿{\mathcal{L}}_{L}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, 𝒩θsubscript𝒩𝜃{\mathcal{N}}_{\theta}caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}}caligraphic_M, ℳμsubscriptℳ𝜇{\mathcal{M}}_{\mu}caligraphic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_μ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and 𝒞βsubscript𝒞𝛽{\mathcal{C}}_{\beta}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_β end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are, respectively, given by
​​​​​​ ​​​​​​

We say a class of operators 𝒜𝒜{\mathcal{A}}caligraphic_A is SRG-full if

∈𝒜⇔𝒢⁢()⊆𝒢⁢(𝒜).formulae-sequenceabsent𝒜⇔𝒢𝒢𝒜\displaystyle{\varbbA}\in{\mathcal{A}}\quad\Leftrightarrow\quad{\mathcal{G}}({% \varbbA})\subseteq{\mathcal{G}}({\mathcal{A}}).∈ caligraphic_A ⇔ caligraphic_G ( ) ⊆ caligraphic_G ( caligraphic_A ) .

In essence, a class is SRG-full when it can be entirely characterized by its SRG.

Fact 3 (Theorem 2, 3 [38]).

Let μ𝜇\muitalic_μ,β𝛽\betaitalic_β,L∈(0,∞)𝐿0L\in(0,\infty)italic_L ∈ ( 0 , ∞ ) and θ∈(0,1)𝜃01\theta\in(0,1)italic_θ ∈ ( 0 , 1 ). Then, ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}}caligraphic_M, ℳμsubscriptℳ𝜇{\mathcal{M}}_{\mu}caligraphic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_μ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, 𝒞βsubscript𝒞𝛽{\mathcal{C}}_{\beta}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_β end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, ℒLsubscriptℒ𝐿{\mathcal{L}}_{L}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and 𝒩θsubscript𝒩𝜃{\mathcal{N}}_{\theta}caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are SRG-full classes. In addition, their intersections are also SRG-full classes.

Fact 4 (Theorem 4, 5 [38]).

If 𝒜𝒜{\mathcal{A}}caligraphic_A is a class of operators, then

𝒢⁢(α⁢𝒜)=α⁢𝒢⁢(𝒜),𝒢⁢(+𝒜)=1+𝒢⁢(𝒜),𝒢⁢(𝒜−1)=𝒢⁢(𝒜)−1.formulae-sequence𝒢𝛼𝒜𝛼𝒢𝒜formulae-sequence𝒢𝒜1𝒢𝒜𝒢superscript𝒜1𝒢superscript𝒜1{\mathcal{G}}(\alpha{\mathcal{A}})=\alpha{\mathcal{G}}({\mathcal{A}}),\quad{% \mathcal{G}}({\varbbI}+{\mathcal{A}})=1+{\mathcal{G}}({\mathcal{A}}),\quad{% \mathcal{G}}({\mathcal{A}}^{-1})={\mathcal{G}}({\mathcal{A}})^{-1}.caligraphic_G ( italic_α caligraphic_A ) = italic_α caligraphic_G ( caligraphic_A ) , caligraphic_G ( + caligraphic_A ) = 1 + caligraphic_G ( caligraphic_A ) , caligraphic_G ( caligraphic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = caligraphic_G ( caligraphic_A ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

where α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is a nonzero real number. If 𝒜𝒜{\mathcal{A}}caligraphic_A is furthermore SRG-full, then α⁢𝒜,+𝒜𝛼𝒜𝒜\alpha{\mathcal{A}},{\varbbI}+{\mathcal{A}}italic_α caligraphic_A , + caligraphic_A, and 𝒜−1superscript𝒜1{\mathcal{A}}^{-1}caligraphic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are SRG-full.

Note that Fact 4 implies that =α⁢𝒜(+α𝒜)−1{}_{\alpha{\mathcal{A}}}=({\varbbI}+\alpha{\mathcal{A}})^{-1}start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_α caligraphic_A end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT = ( + italic_α caligraphic_A ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is an SRG-full class for α>0𝛼0\alpha>0italic_α > 0 provided that 𝒜𝒜{\mathcal{A}}caligraphic_A is an SRG-full class.

Fact 5.

If 𝒜𝒜{\mathcal{A}}caligraphic_A is an SRG-full class and

∥u−v∥∥x−y∥⁢exp⁡[i⁢∠⁢(u−v,x−y)]∈𝒢⁢(𝒜)delimited-∥∥𝑢𝑣delimited-∥∥𝑥𝑦𝑖∠𝑢𝑣𝑥𝑦𝒢𝒜\frac{\lVert u-v\rVert}{\lVert x-y\rVert}\exp[i\angle(u-v,x-y)]\in{\mathcal{G}% }\left({\mathcal{A}}\right)divide start_ARG ∥ italic_u - italic_v ∥ end_ARG start_ARG ∥ italic_x - italic_y ∥ end_ARG roman_exp [ italic_i ∠ ( italic_u - italic_v , italic_x - italic_y ) ] ∈ caligraphic_G ( caligraphic_A )

for any u𝑢uitalic_u, v𝑣vitalic_v, x𝑥xitalic_x, y∈ℋ𝑦ℋy\in{\mathcal{H}}italic_y ∈ caligraphic_H with x≠y𝑥𝑦x\neq yitalic_x ≠ italic_y, there exists a single-valued operator ∈𝒜absent𝒜{\varbbA}\in{\mathcal{A}}∈ caligraphic_A such that

x=u,y=v.formulae-sequence𝑥𝑢𝑦𝑣{\varbbA}x=u,\quad{\varbbA}y=v.italic_x = italic_u , italic_y = italic_v .

Proof.

Define ={(x,u),(y,v)}absent𝑥𝑢𝑦𝑣{\varbbA}=\{(x,u),(y,v)\}= { ( italic_x , italic_u ) , ( italic_y , italic_v ) }. Then,

𝒢⁢()=∥u−v∥∥x−y∥⁢exp⁡[±i⁢∠⁢(u−v,x−y)]⊆𝒢⁢(𝒜)𝒢delimited-∥∥𝑢𝑣delimited-∥∥𝑥𝑦plus-or-minus𝑖∠𝑢𝑣𝑥𝑦𝒢𝒜{\mathcal{G}}\left({\varbbA}\right)=\frac{\lVert u-v\rVert}{\lVert x-y\rVert}% \exp[\pm i\angle(u-v,x-y)]\subseteq{\mathcal{G}}\left({\mathcal{A}}\right)caligraphic_G ( ) = divide start_ARG ∥ italic_u - italic_v ∥ end_ARG start_ARG ∥ italic_x - italic_y ∥ end_ARG roman_exp [ ± italic_i ∠ ( italic_u - italic_v , italic_x - italic_y ) ] ⊆ caligraphic_G ( caligraphic_A )

holds, so ∈𝒜absent𝒜{\varbbA}\in{\mathcal{A}}∈ caligraphic_A by SRG-fullness.

Fact 6.

Let ℋℋ{\mathcal{H}}caligraphic_H be a real Hilbert space. If :ℋ⇉ℋ:absent⇉ℋℋ{\varbbA}\colon{\mathcal{H}}\rightrightarrows{\mathcal{H}}: caligraphic_H ⇉ caligraphic_H is a single-valued operator such that domdom\mathrm{dom}\,{\varbbA}roman_dom is a singleton, is an element of any SRG-full class.

Proof.

𝒢⁢()=∅𝒢{\mathcal{G}}\left({\varbbA}\right)=\emptysetcaligraphic_G ( ) = ∅ is a subset of the SRG of any SRG-full class.

Arc property

Denote z¯¯𝑧\overline{z}over¯ start_ARG italic_z end_ARG the conjugate of z∈ℂ𝑧ℂz\in\mathbb{C}italic_z ∈ blackboard_C. Define the right-hand arc between z,z¯∈ℂ𝑧¯𝑧ℂz,\overline{z}\in\mathbb{C}italic_z , over¯ start_ARG italic_z end_ARG ∈ blackboard_C as

Arc+⁢(z,z¯)={r⁢ei⁢(1−2⁢θ)⁢φ|z=r⁢ei⁢φ,φ∈(−π,π],r≥0,θ∈[0,1]}superscriptArc𝑧¯𝑧conditional-set𝑟superscript𝑒𝑖12𝜃𝜑formulae-sequence𝑧𝑟superscript𝑒𝑖𝜑formulae-sequence𝜑𝜋𝜋formulae-sequence𝑟0𝜃01\mathrm{Arc}^{+}(z,\overline{z})=\left\{re^{i(1-2\theta)\varphi}\,\middle|\,z=% re^{i\varphi},\varphi\in(-\pi,\pi],r\geq 0,\theta\in[0,1]\right\}roman_Arc start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_z , over¯ start_ARG italic_z end_ARG ) = { italic_r italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i ( 1 - 2 italic_θ ) italic_φ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_z = italic_r italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i italic_φ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_φ ∈ ( - italic_π , italic_π ] , italic_r ≥ 0 , italic_θ ∈ [ 0 , 1 ] }

and the left-hand arc between z𝑧zitalic_z and z¯¯𝑧\overline{z}over¯ start_ARG italic_z end_ARG as

Arc−⁢(z,z¯)=−Arc+⁢(−z,−z¯).superscriptArc𝑧¯𝑧superscriptArc𝑧¯𝑧\mathrm{Arc}^{-}(z,\overline{z})=-\mathrm{Arc}^{+}(-z,-\overline{z}).roman_Arc start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_z , over¯ start_ARG italic_z end_ARG ) = - roman_Arc start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( - italic_z , - over¯ start_ARG italic_z end_ARG ) .

Note that both r𝑟ritalic_r and φ𝜑\varphiitalic_φ used in defining the right-hand arc are uniquely determined unless z=0𝑧0z=0italic_z = 0, so the set defines an arc, not a cone. If an SRG-full class 𝒜𝒜{\mathcal{A}}caligraphic_A satisfies

Arc+⁢(z,z¯)⊆𝒢⁢(𝒜),∀z∈𝒢⁢(𝒜)∖{∞},formulae-sequencesuperscriptArc𝑧¯𝑧𝒢𝒜for-all𝑧𝒢𝒜\mathrm{Arc}^{+}(z,\overline{z})\subseteq{\mathcal{G}}\left({\mathcal{A}}% \right),\qquad\forall z\in{\mathcal{G}}\left({\mathcal{A}}\right)\setminus\{% \infty\},roman_Arc start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_z , over¯ start_ARG italic_z end_ARG ) ⊆ caligraphic_G ( caligraphic_A ) , ∀ italic_z ∈ caligraphic_G ( caligraphic_A ) ∖ { ∞ } ,

we say 𝒜𝒜{\mathcal{A}}caligraphic_A satisfies the right-arc property. Similarly, if

Arc−⁢(z,z¯)⊆𝒢⁢(𝒜),∀z∈𝒢⁢(𝒜)∖{∞},formulae-sequencesuperscriptArc𝑧¯𝑧𝒢𝒜for-all𝑧𝒢𝒜\mathrm{Arc}^{-}(z,\overline{z})\subseteq{\mathcal{G}}\left({\mathcal{A}}% \right),\qquad\forall z\in{\mathcal{G}}\left({\mathcal{A}}\right)\setminus\{% \infty\},roman_Arc start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_z , over¯ start_ARG italic_z end_ARG ) ⊆ caligraphic_G ( caligraphic_A ) , ∀ italic_z ∈ caligraphic_G ( caligraphic_A ) ∖ { ∞ } ,

holds, we say 𝒜𝒜{\mathcal{A}}caligraphic_A has the left-arc property. If an SRG-full class 𝒜𝒜{\mathcal{A}}caligraphic_A has either the right-arc property or the left-arc property, then it is said to have an arc property.

The maximum modulus theorem

Define the boundary of A⊆ℂ𝐴ℂA\subseteq\mathbb{C}italic_A ⊆ blackboard_C as ∂A=cl⁢A∖int⁢A𝐴cl𝐴int𝐴\partial A=\mathrm{cl}{A}\setminus\mathrm{int}A∂ italic_A = roman_cl italic_A ∖ roman_int italic_A, where cl⁢Acl𝐴\mathrm{cl}{A}roman_cl italic_A and int⁢Aint𝐴\mathrm{int}Aroman_int italic_A are the closure and interior of A𝐴Aitalic_A, respectively.

Fact 7 (The maximum modulus theorem [42]).

Let D⊂ℂ𝐷ℂD\subset\mathbb{C}italic_D ⊂ blackboard_C be a compact set. If h:ℂ→ℂ:ℎ→ℂℂh\colon\mathbb{C}\rightarrow\mathbb{C}italic_h : blackboard_C → blackboard_C is holomorphic on all of ℂℂ\,\mathbb{C}blackboard_C, then maxz∈D⁡|h⁢(z)|subscript𝑧𝐷ℎ𝑧\max_{z\in D}|h(z)|roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z ∈ italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_h ( italic_z ) | is attained at some point of ∂D𝐷\partial D∂ italic_D.

This maximum modulus theorem simplifies our calculations of Sections 3 and 4 via the following lemma.

Lemma 1.1.

Let f:ℂ3→ℂ:𝑓→superscriptℂ3ℂf\colon\mathbb{C}^{3}\to\mathbb{C}italic_f : blackboard_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_C be a polynomial of three complex variables. Let A𝐴Aitalic_A, B𝐵Bitalic_B, and C𝐶Citalic_C be compact subsets of ℂℂ\,\mathbb{C}blackboard_C. Then,

maxzA∈A,zB∈B,zC∈C⁡|f⁢(zA,zB,zC)|=maxzA∈∂A,zB∈∂B,zC∈∂C⁡|f⁢(zA,zB,zC)|.subscriptformulae-sequencesubscript𝑧𝐴𝐴subscript𝑧𝐵𝐵subscript𝑧𝐶𝐶𝑓subscript𝑧𝐴subscript𝑧𝐵subscript𝑧𝐶subscriptformulae-sequencesubscript𝑧𝐴𝐴subscript𝑧𝐵𝐵subscript𝑧𝐶𝐶𝑓subscript𝑧𝐴subscript𝑧𝐵subscript𝑧𝐶\max_{\begin{subarray}{c}z_{A}\in A,z_{B}\in B,\\ z_{C}\in C\end{subarray}}\lvert f(z_{A},z_{B},z_{C})\rvert=\max_{\begin{% subarray}{c}z_{A}\in\partial A,z_{B}\in\partial B,\\ z_{C}\in\partial C\end{subarray}}\lvert f(z_{A},z_{B},z_{C})\rvert.roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ italic_A , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ italic_B , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ italic_C end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_f ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) | = roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ ∂ italic_A , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ ∂ italic_B , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ ∂ italic_C end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_f ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) | .

Proof 1.2.

As f𝑓fitalic_f is a polynomial, |f|𝑓\lvert f\rvert| italic_f | is continuous on its compact domain A×B×C⊂ℂ3𝐴𝐵𝐶superscriptℂ3A\times B\times C\subset\mathbb{C}^{3}italic_A × italic_B × italic_C ⊂ blackboard_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Hence, |f|𝑓\lvert f\rvert| italic_f | attains its maximum at some point (zA0,zB0,zC0)∈A×B×Csuperscriptsubscript𝑧𝐴0superscriptsubscript𝑧𝐵0superscriptsubscript𝑧𝐶0𝐴𝐵𝐶(z_{A}^{0},z_{B}^{0},z_{C}^{0})\in A\times B\times C( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∈ italic_A × italic_B × italic_C.

Furthermore, f𝑓fitalic_f is holomorphic in each argument with the other two arguments fixed as it is a polynomial. Then, if we fix zB=zB0subscript𝑧𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑧𝐵0z_{B}=z_{B}^{0}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and zC=zC0subscript𝑧𝐶superscriptsubscript𝑧𝐶0z_{C}=z_{C}^{0}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, there exists some zA1∈∂Asuperscriptsubscript𝑧𝐴1𝐴z_{A}^{1}\in\partial Aitalic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ ∂ italic_A such that

|f⁢(zA1,zB0,zC0)|=|f⁢(zA0,zB0,zC0)|𝑓superscriptsubscript𝑧𝐴1superscriptsubscript𝑧𝐵0superscriptsubscript𝑧𝐶0𝑓superscriptsubscript𝑧𝐴0superscriptsubscript𝑧𝐵0superscriptsubscript𝑧𝐶0\lvert f(z_{A}^{1},z_{B}^{0},z_{C}^{0})\rvert=\lvert f(z_{A}^{0},z_{B}^{0},z_{% C}^{0})\rvert| italic_f ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) | = | italic_f ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) |

by Fact 7. Applying similar procedure with respect to other arguments, we obtain zB1∈∂Bsuperscriptsubscript𝑧𝐵1𝐵z_{B}^{1}\in\partial Bitalic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ ∂ italic_B and zC1∈∂Csuperscriptsubscript𝑧𝐶1𝐶z_{C}^{1}\in\partial Citalic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ ∂ italic_C such that

|f⁢(zA1,zB1,zC1)|𝑓superscriptsubscript𝑧𝐴1superscriptsubscript𝑧𝐵1superscriptsubscript𝑧𝐶1\displaystyle\lvert f(z_{A}^{1},z_{B}^{1},z_{C}^{1})\rvert| italic_f ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) | =|f⁢(zA0,zB0,zC0)|absent𝑓superscriptsubscript𝑧𝐴0superscriptsubscript𝑧𝐵0superscriptsubscript𝑧𝐶0\displaystyle=\lvert f(z_{A}^{0},z_{B}^{0},z_{C}^{0})\rvert= | italic_f ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) |
=maxzA∈A,zB∈B,zC∈C⁡|f⁢(zA,zB,zC)|.absentsubscriptformulae-sequencesubscript𝑧𝐴𝐴formulae-sequencesubscript𝑧𝐵𝐵subscript𝑧𝐶𝐶𝑓subscript𝑧𝐴subscript𝑧𝐵subscript𝑧𝐶\displaystyle=\max_{z_{A}\in A,z_{B}\in B,z_{C}\in C}\,\lvert f(z_{A},z_{B},z_% {C})\rvert.= roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ italic_A , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ italic_B , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_f ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) | .

2 SRG theory

Let

,,,α,λ =(1−λ)+λ(−+α(2−α−α)αα)\displaystyle=(1-\lambda){\varbbI}+\lambda\left({\varbbI}-{}_{\alpha{\varbbB}}% +{}_{\alpha{\varbbA}}(2{}_{\alpha{\varbbB}}-{\varbbI}-\alpha{\varbbC}{}_{% \alpha{\varbbB}})\right)= ( 1 - italic_λ ) + italic_λ ( - start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT + start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT ( 2 start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT - - italic_α start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT ) )
=−λ+αλ(2−α−α)αα\displaystyle={\varbbI}-\lambda{}_{\alpha{\varbbB}}+\lambda{}_{\alpha{\varbbA}% }(2{}_{\alpha{\varbbB}}-{\varbbI}-\alpha{\varbbC}{}_{\alpha{\varbbB}})= - italic_λ start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT + italic_λ start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT ( 2 start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT - - italic_α start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT )

be the (averaged) DYS operator for operators :ℋ⇉ℋ:absent⇉ℋℋ{\varbbA}\colon{\mathcal{H}}\rightrightarrows{\mathcal{H}}: caligraphic_H ⇉ caligraphic_H, :ℋ⇉ℋ:absent⇉ℋℋ{\varbbB}\colon{\mathcal{H}}\rightrightarrows{\mathcal{H}}: caligraphic_H ⇉ caligraphic_H, and :ℋ⇉ℋ:absent⇉ℋℋ{\varbbC}\colon{\mathcal{H}}\rightrightarrows{\mathcal{H}}: caligraphic_H ⇉ caligraphic_H with stepsize α∈(0,∞)𝛼0\alpha\in(0,\infty)italic_α ∈ ( 0 , ∞ ) and averaging parameter λ∈(0,∞)𝜆0\lambda\in(0,\infty)italic_λ ∈ ( 0 , ∞ ). Let

=𝒜,ℬ,𝒞,α,λ{|,,,α,λ∈𝒜,∈ℬ,∈𝒞}{}_{{\mathcal{A}},{\mathcal{B}},{\mathcal{C}},\alpha,\lambda}=\left\{{}_{{% \varbbA},{\varbbB},{\varbbC},\alpha,\lambda}\,|\,{\varbbA}\in{\mathcal{A}},{% \varbbB}\in{\mathcal{B}},{\varbbC}\in{\mathcal{C}}\right\}start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_A , caligraphic_B , caligraphic_C , italic_α , italic_λ end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT = { start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT , , , italic_α , italic_λ end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT | ∈ caligraphic_A , ∈ caligraphic_B , ∈ caligraphic_C }

be the class of DYS operators for operator classes 𝒜𝒜{\mathcal{A}}caligraphic_A, ℬℬ{\mathcal{B}}caligraphic_B, and 𝒞𝒞{\mathcal{C}}caligraphic_C with α,λ∈(0,∞)𝛼𝜆0\alpha,\lambda\in(0,\infty)italic_α , italic_λ ∈ ( 0 , ∞ ). Analogously, define

ζDYS⁢(zA,zB,zC;α,λ)subscript𝜁DYSsubscript𝑧𝐴subscript𝑧𝐵subscript𝑧𝐶𝛼𝜆\displaystyle\zeta_{\text{DYS}}(z_{A},z_{B},z_{C};\alpha,\lambda)italic_ζ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT DYS end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_α , italic_λ ) =1−λ⁢zB+λ⁢zA⁢(2⁢zB−1−α⁢zC⁢zB)absent1𝜆subscript𝑧𝐵𝜆subscript𝑧𝐴2subscript𝑧𝐵1𝛼subscript𝑧𝐶subscript𝑧𝐵\displaystyle=1-\lambda z_{B}+\lambda z_{A}(2z_{B}-1-\alpha z_{C}z_{B})= 1 - italic_λ italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_λ italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 2 italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 1 - italic_α italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
=1−λ⁢zA−λ⁢zB+λ⁢(2−α⁢zC)⁢zA⁢zBabsent1𝜆subscript𝑧𝐴𝜆subscript𝑧𝐵𝜆2𝛼subscript𝑧𝐶subscript𝑧𝐴subscript𝑧𝐵\displaystyle=1-\lambda z_{A}-\lambda z_{B}+\lambda(2-\alpha z_{C})z_{A}z_{B}= 1 - italic_λ italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_λ italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_λ ( 2 - italic_α italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT

and

𝒵𝒜,ℬ,𝒞,α,λDYS={ζDYS(zA,zB,zC;α,λ)|zA∈𝒢()α⁢𝒜,zB∈𝒢()α⁢ℬ,zC∈𝒢(𝒞)}{\mathcal{Z}}^{\text{DYS}}_{{\mathcal{A}},{\mathcal{B}},{\mathcal{C}},\alpha,% \lambda}=\left\{\zeta_{\text{DYS}}(z_{A},z_{B},z_{C};\alpha,\lambda)\,|\,z_{A}% \in{\mathcal{G}}\left({}_{\alpha{\mathcal{A}}}\right),z_{B}\in{\mathcal{G}}% \left({}_{\alpha{\mathcal{B}}}\right),z_{C}\in{\mathcal{G}}\left({\mathcal{C}}% \right)\right\}caligraphic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT DYS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_A , caligraphic_B , caligraphic_C , italic_α , italic_λ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_ζ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT DYS end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_α , italic_λ ) | italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_G ( start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_α caligraphic_A end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_G ( start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_α caligraphic_B end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_G ( caligraphic_C ) }

for operator classes 𝒜𝒜{\mathcal{A}}caligraphic_A, ℬℬ{\mathcal{B}}caligraphic_B, and 𝒞𝒞{\mathcal{C}}caligraphic_C with α,λ∈(0,∞)𝛼𝜆0\alpha,\lambda\in(0,\infty)italic_α , italic_λ ∈ ( 0 , ∞ ). In the Theorems 3.1, 3.2, and 3.3 that we later prove, the fact that ζDYS⁢(zA,zB,zC;α,λ)subscript𝜁DYSsubscript𝑧𝐴subscript𝑧𝐵subscript𝑧𝐶𝛼𝜆\zeta_{\text{DYS}}(z_{A},z_{B},z_{C};\alpha,\lambda)italic_ζ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT DYS end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_α , italic_λ ) is symmetric in zAsubscript𝑧𝐴z_{A}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and zBsubscript𝑧𝐵z_{B}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT will play an important role.

In this section, we establish the correspondence between A,B,C,α,λ and 𝒵𝒜,ℬ,𝒞,α,λDYSsubscriptsuperscript𝒵DYS𝒜ℬ𝒞𝛼𝜆{\mathcal{Z}}^{\text{DYS}}_{{\mathcal{A}},{\mathcal{B}},{\mathcal{C}},\alpha,\lambda}caligraphic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT DYS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_A , caligraphic_B , caligraphic_C , italic_α , italic_λ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT through the following theorem.

Theorem 2.1.

Let α,λ∈(0,∞)𝛼𝜆0\alpha,\lambda\in(0,\infty)italic_α , italic_λ ∈ ( 0 , ∞ ). Let 𝒜𝒜{\mathcal{A}}caligraphic_A and ℬℬ{\mathcal{B}}caligraphic_B be SRG-full classes of monotone operators and assume +α⁢𝒜𝛼𝒜{\varbbI}+\alpha{\mathcal{A}}+ italic_α caligraphic_A has the right-arc property. Let 𝒞𝒞{\mathcal{C}}caligraphic_C be an SRG-full class of single-valued operators. Assume 𝒢⁢(𝒜)𝒢𝒜{\mathcal{G}}\left({\mathcal{A}}\right)caligraphic_G ( caligraphic_A ), 𝒢⁢(ℬ)𝒢ℬ{\mathcal{G}}\left({\mathcal{B}}\right)caligraphic_G ( caligraphic_B ), 𝒢⁢(𝒞)≠∅𝒢𝒞{\mathcal{G}}\left({\mathcal{C}}\right)\neq\emptysetcaligraphic_G ( caligraphic_C ) ≠ ∅. If s≠1𝑠1s\neq 1italic_s ≠ 1 is a real number such that (2−λ⁢(1−s)−1)−α⁢𝒞2𝜆superscript1𝑠1𝛼𝒞(2-\lambda(1-s)^{-1}){\varbbI}-\alpha{\mathcal{C}}( 2 - italic_λ ( 1 - italic_s ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_α caligraphic_C has an arc property, then

|𝒢()𝒜,ℬ,𝒞,α,λ−s|=|𝒵𝒜,ℬ,𝒞,α,λDYS−s|.\lvert{\mathcal{G}}\left({}_{{\mathcal{A}},{\mathcal{B}},{\mathcal{C}},\alpha,% \lambda}\right)-s\rvert=\left|{\mathcal{Z}}^{\text{DYS}}_{{\mathcal{A}},{% \mathcal{B}},{\mathcal{C}},\alpha,\lambda}-s\right|.| caligraphic_G ( start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_A , caligraphic_B , caligraphic_C , italic_α , italic_λ end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_s | = | caligraphic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT DYS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_A , caligraphic_B , caligraphic_C , italic_α , italic_λ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_s | .

In Section 4, we use Theorem 2.1 with s≠0𝑠0s\neq 0italic_s ≠ 0. In Section 3, we use Theorem 2.1 with s=0𝑠0s=0italic_s = 0 to obtain contraction factors of the DYS operator by bounding the maximum modulus of 𝒵𝒜,ℬ,𝒞,α,λDYSsubscriptsuperscript𝒵DYS𝒜ℬ𝒞𝛼𝜆{\mathcal{Z}}^{\text{DYS}}_{{\mathcal{A}},{\mathcal{B}},{\mathcal{C}},\alpha,\lambda}caligraphic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT DYS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_A , caligraphic_B , caligraphic_C , italic_α , italic_λ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as described in the following corollary.

Corollary 2.2.

Let 𝒜𝒜{\mathcal{A}}caligraphic_A, ℬℬ{\mathcal{B}}caligraphic_B, 𝒞𝒞{\mathcal{C}}caligraphic_C, α𝛼\alphaitalic_α, and λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ be as in Theorem 2.1 and (2−λ)−α⁢𝒞2𝜆𝛼𝒞(2-\lambda){\varbbI}-\alpha{\mathcal{C}}( 2 - italic_λ ) - italic_α caligraphic_C has an arc property.) Then,

sup∈𝒜,ℬ,𝒞,α,λx,y∈dom,x≠y∥x−y∥∥x−y∥=supz∈𝒵𝒜,ℬ,𝒞,α,λDYS|z|.\sup_{\begin{subarray}{c}{\varbbT}\in{}_{{\mathcal{A}},{\mathcal{B}},{\mathcal% {C}},\alpha,\lambda}\\ x,y\in\mathrm{dom}\,{\varbbT},\,x\neq y\end{subarray}}\frac{\lVert{\varbbT}x-{% \varbbT}y\rVert}{\lVert x-y\rVert}=\sup_{z\in{\mathcal{Z}}^{\text{DYS}}_{{% \mathcal{A}},{\mathcal{B}},{\mathcal{C}},\alpha,\lambda}}\lvert z\rvert.roman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL ∈ start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_A , caligraphic_B , caligraphic_C , italic_α , italic_λ end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_x , italic_y ∈ roman_dom , italic_x ≠ italic_y end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG ∥ italic_x - italic_y ∥ end_ARG start_ARG ∥ italic_x - italic_y ∥ end_ARG = roman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z ∈ caligraphic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT DYS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_A , caligraphic_B , caligraphic_C , italic_α , italic_λ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z | .

Proof 2.3.

With s=0𝑠0s=0italic_s = 0 in Theorem 2.1, we have

|𝒢()𝒜,ℬ,𝒞,α,λ|=|𝒵𝒜,ℬ,𝒞,α,λDYS|.\lvert{\mathcal{G}}\left({}_{{\mathcal{A}},{\mathcal{B}},{\mathcal{C}},\alpha,% \lambda}\right)\rvert=\left|{\mathcal{Z}}^{\text{DYS}}_{{\mathcal{A}},{% \mathcal{B}},{\mathcal{C}},\alpha,\lambda}\right|.| caligraphic_G ( start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_A , caligraphic_B , caligraphic_C , italic_α , italic_λ end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT ) | = | caligraphic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT DYS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_A , caligraphic_B , caligraphic_C , italic_α , italic_λ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | .

and the left-hand side can be expressed as

|𝒢()𝒜,ℬ,𝒞,α,λ|={∥x−y∥∥x−y∥|∈,𝒜,ℬ,𝒞,α,λx,y∈dom,x≠y}.\lvert{\mathcal{G}}\left({}_{{\mathcal{A}},{\mathcal{B}},{\mathcal{C}},\alpha,% \lambda}\right)\rvert=\left\{\frac{\lVert{\varbbT}x-{\varbbT}y\rVert}{\lVert x% -y\rVert}\,\middle|\,{\varbbT}\in{}_{{\mathcal{A}},{\mathcal{B}},{\mathcal{C}}% ,\alpha,\lambda},\,x,y\in\mathrm{dom}\,{\varbbT},\,x\neq y\right\}.| caligraphic_G ( start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_A , caligraphic_B , caligraphic_C , italic_α , italic_λ end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT ) | = { divide start_ARG ∥ italic_x - italic_y ∥ end_ARG start_ARG ∥ italic_x - italic_y ∥ end_ARG | ∈ start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_A , caligraphic_B , caligraphic_C , italic_α , italic_λ end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT , italic_x , italic_y ∈ roman_dom , italic_x ≠ italic_y } .

Notably, Corollary 2.2 allows one to compute the tight contraction factor by calculating the maximum modulus of a set of complex numbers 𝒵𝒜,ℬ,𝒞,α,λDYSsubscriptsuperscript𝒵DYS𝒜ℬ𝒞𝛼𝜆{\mathcal{Z}}^{\text{DYS}}_{{\mathcal{A}},{\mathcal{B}},{\mathcal{C}},\alpha,\lambda}caligraphic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT DYS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_A , caligraphic_B , caligraphic_C , italic_α , italic_λ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or, equivalently, by bounding the maximum of |ζDYS⁢(zA,zB,zC;α,λ)|subscript𝜁DYSsubscript𝑧𝐴subscript𝑧𝐵subscript𝑧𝐶𝛼𝜆|\zeta_{\text{DYS}}(z_{A},z_{B},z_{C};\alpha,\lambda)|| italic_ζ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT DYS end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_α , italic_λ ) | subject to the constraints zA∈𝒢()α⁢𝒜,z_{A}\in{\mathcal{G}}\left({}_{\alpha{\mathcal{A}}}\right),italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_G ( start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_α caligraphic_A end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT ) , zB∈𝒢()α⁢ℬ,z_{B}\in{\mathcal{G}}\left({}_{\alpha{\mathcal{B}}}\right),italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_G ( start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_α caligraphic_B end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT ) , and zC∈𝒢⁢(𝒞)subscript𝑧𝐶𝒢𝒞z_{C}\in{\mathcal{G}}\left({\mathcal{C}}\right)italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_G ( caligraphic_C ) on the inputs to the complex polynomial ζDYSsubscript𝜁DYS\zeta_{\text{DYS}}italic_ζ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT DYS end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

The arc property requirement on 𝒞𝒞{\mathcal{C}}caligraphic_C holds under the standard assumption that is cocoercive. Specifically, if α𝛼\alphaitalic_α, β𝒞∈(0,∞)subscript𝛽𝒞0\beta_{\mathcal{C}}\in(0,\infty)italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ ( 0 , ∞ ) and 𝒞=𝒞β𝒞𝒞subscript𝒞subscript𝛽𝒞{\mathcal{C}}={\mathcal{C}}_{\beta_{\mathcal{C}}}caligraphic_C = caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then 𝒢⁢((2−λ)−α⁢𝒞)𝒢2𝜆𝛼𝒞{\mathcal{G}}\left((2-\lambda){\varbbI}-\alpha{\mathcal{C}}\right)caligraphic_G ( ( 2 - italic_λ ) - italic_α caligraphic_C ) is a disk with its center on the real axis, thus an arc property is satisfied. However, the conclusion of Corollary 2.2 may fail if the arc property is not satisfied, as we demonstrate in the arXiv version of this paper [27] by comparing the maximum modulus with tight factor obtained using the performance estimation problem (PEP) framework [20, 43, 39].

When the arc property fails, we can consider an enlarged class 𝒞′⊃𝒞𝒞superscript𝒞′{\mathcal{C}}^{\prime}\supset{\mathcal{C}}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊃ caligraphic_C such that (2−λ)−α⁢𝒞′2𝜆𝛼superscript𝒞′(2-\lambda){\varbbI}-\alpha{\mathcal{C}}^{\prime}( 2 - italic_λ ) - italic_α caligraphic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT does satisfy an arc property.

Corollary 2.4.

Let 𝒜𝒜{\mathcal{A}}caligraphic_A, ℬℬ{\mathcal{B}}caligraphic_B, α𝛼\alphaitalic_α, and λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ be as in Theorem 2.1 and let s=0𝑠0s=0italic_s = 0. Assume 𝒞𝒞{\mathcal{C}}caligraphic_C is a class of single-valued operators, but do not assume that (2−λ)−α⁢𝒞2𝜆𝛼𝒞(2-\lambda){\varbbI}-\alpha{\mathcal{C}}( 2 - italic_λ ) - italic_α caligraphic_C has an arc property. If there exists some SRG-full class 𝒞′superscript𝒞′{\mathcal{C}}^{\prime}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of single-valued operators such that

𝒞′⊇𝒞,(2−λ)−α⁢𝒞′⁢ has an arc property𝒞2𝜆𝛼superscript𝒞′ has an arc propertysuperscript𝒞′{\mathcal{C}}^{\prime}\supseteq{\mathcal{C}},\quad(2-\lambda){\varbbI}-\alpha{% \mathcal{C}}^{\prime}\text{ has an arc property}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊇ caligraphic_C , ( 2 - italic_λ ) - italic_α caligraphic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has an arc property

then

sup∈𝒜,ℬ,𝒞,α,λx,y∈dom,x≠y∥x−y∥∥x−y∥≤supz∈𝒵𝒜,ℬ,𝒞′,α,λDYS|z|.\sup_{\begin{subarray}{c}{\varbbT}\in{}_{{\mathcal{A}},{\mathcal{B}},{\mathcal% {C}},\alpha,\lambda}\\ x,y\in\mathrm{dom}\,{\varbbT},x\neq y\end{subarray}}\frac{\lVert{\varbbT}x-{% \varbbT}y\rVert}{\lVert x-y\rVert}\leq\sup_{z\in{\mathcal{Z}}^{\text{DYS}}_{{% \mathcal{A}},{\mathcal{B}},{\mathcal{C}}^{\prime},\alpha,\lambda}}\lvert z\rvert.roman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL ∈ start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_A , caligraphic_B , caligraphic_C , italic_α , italic_λ end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_x , italic_y ∈ roman_dom , italic_x ≠ italic_y end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG ∥ italic_x - italic_y ∥ end_ARG start_ARG ∥ italic_x - italic_y ∥ end_ARG ≤ roman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z ∈ caligraphic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT DYS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_A , caligraphic_B , caligraphic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_α , italic_λ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z | .

(The right-hand side depends on 𝒞′superscript𝒞′{\mathcal{C}}^{\prime}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, rather than 𝒞𝒞{\mathcal{C}}caligraphic_C.)

Proof 2.5.

Since 𝒞⊆𝒞′𝒞superscript𝒞′{\mathcal{C}}\subseteq{\mathcal{C}}^{\prime}caligraphic_C ⊆ caligraphic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we have ⊆𝒜,ℬ,𝒞,α,λ𝒜,ℬ,𝒞′,α,λ{}_{{\mathcal{A}},{\mathcal{B}},{\mathcal{C}},\alpha,\lambda}\subseteq{}_{{% \mathcal{A}},{\mathcal{B}},{\mathcal{C}}^{\prime},\alpha,\lambda}start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_A , caligraphic_B , caligraphic_C , italic_α , italic_λ end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT ⊆ start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_A , caligraphic_B , caligraphic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_α , italic_λ end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT. Therefore,

sup∈𝒜,ℬ,𝒞,α,λx,y∈dom,x≠y∥x−y∥∥x−y∥≤sup∈𝒜,ℬ,𝒞′,α,λx,y∈dom,x≠y∥x−y∥∥x−y∥=supz∈𝒵𝒜,ℬ,𝒞′,α,λDYS|z|,\sup_{\begin{subarray}{c}{\varbbT}\in{}_{{\mathcal{A}},{\mathcal{B}},{\mathcal% {C}},\alpha,\lambda}\\ x,y\in\mathrm{dom}\,{\varbbT},\,x\neq y\end{subarray}}\frac{\lVert{\varbbT}x-{% \varbbT}y\rVert}{\lVert x-y\rVert}\leq\sup_{\begin{subarray}{c}{\varbbT}\in{}_% {{\mathcal{A}},{\mathcal{B}},{\mathcal{C}}^{\prime},\alpha,\lambda}\\ x,y\in\mathrm{dom}\,{\varbbT},\,x\neq y\end{subarray}}\frac{\lVert{\varbbT}x-{% \varbbT}y\rVert}{\lVert x-y\rVert}=\sup_{z\in{\mathcal{Z}}^{\text{DYS}}_{{% \mathcal{A}},{\mathcal{B}},{\mathcal{C}}^{\prime},\alpha,\lambda}}\lvert z\rvert,roman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL ∈ start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_A , caligraphic_B , caligraphic_C , italic_α , italic_λ end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_x , italic_y ∈ roman_dom , italic_x ≠ italic_y end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG ∥ italic_x - italic_y ∥ end_ARG start_ARG ∥ italic_x - italic_y ∥ end_ARG ≤ roman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL ∈ start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_A , caligraphic_B , caligraphic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_α , italic_λ end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_x , italic_y ∈ roman_dom , italic_x ≠ italic_y end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG ∥ italic_x - italic_y ∥ end_ARG start_ARG ∥ italic_x - italic_y ∥ end_ARG = roman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z ∈ caligraphic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT DYS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_A , caligraphic_B , caligraphic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_α , italic_λ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z | ,

where the last equality follows from Corollary 2.2.

Note that we can apply Theorem 2.1, as well as Corollaries 2.2 and 2.4, for 𝒜=ℳμ𝒜∩𝒞β𝒜∩ℒL𝒜𝒜subscriptℳsubscript𝜇𝒜subscript𝒞subscript𝛽𝒜subscriptℒsubscript𝐿𝒜{\mathcal{A}}={\mathcal{M}}_{\mu_{\mathcal{A}}}\cap{\mathcal{C}}_{\beta_{% \mathcal{A}}}\cap{\mathcal{L}}_{L_{\mathcal{A}}}caligraphic_A = caligraphic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∩ caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∩ caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where μ𝒜∈[0,∞)subscript𝜇𝒜0\mu_{\mathcal{A}}\in[0,\infty)italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ [ 0 , ∞ ), β𝒜∈[0,∞)subscript𝛽𝒜0\beta_{\mathcal{A}}\in[0,\infty)italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ [ 0 , ∞ ), and L𝒜∈(0,∞]subscript𝐿𝒜0L_{\mathcal{A}}\in(0,\infty]italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ ( 0 , ∞ ]. (This includes classes like ℳ∩ℒL𝒜ℳsubscriptℒsubscript𝐿𝒜{\mathcal{M}}\cap{\mathcal{L}}_{L_{\mathcal{A}}}caligraphic_M ∩ caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by setting μ𝒜=β𝒜=0subscript𝜇𝒜subscript𝛽𝒜0\mu_{\mathcal{A}}=\beta_{\mathcal{A}}=0italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.) To see this, observe that SRGs of +α⁢ℳμ𝒜𝛼subscriptℳsubscript𝜇𝒜{\varbbI}+\alpha{\mathcal{M}}_{\mu_{\mathcal{A}}}+ italic_α caligraphic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, +α⁢𝒞β𝒜𝛼subscript𝒞subscript𝛽𝒜{\varbbI}+\alpha{\mathcal{C}}_{\beta_{\mathcal{A}}}+ italic_α caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and +α⁢ℒL𝒜𝛼subscriptℒsubscript𝐿𝒜{\varbbI}+\alpha{\mathcal{L}}_{L_{\mathcal{A}}}+ italic_α caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are in form of a disk with its center being a nonnegative real number or {z∈ℂ|Re⁡z≥a}conditional-set𝑧ℂRe𝑧𝑎\left\{z\in\mathbb{C}\,|\,\operatorname{Re}z\geq a\right\}{ italic_z ∈ blackboard_C | roman_Re italic_z ≥ italic_a } for some nonnegative a𝑎aitalic_a and thus satisfy the right-arc property. Therefore, +α⁢𝒜𝛼𝒜{\varbbI}+\alpha{\mathcal{A}}+ italic_α caligraphic_A, as an intersection of them, is an SRG-full class of monotone operators satisfying the right-arc property.

The remainder of this section proves Theorem 2.1 with the following structure. Section 2.1 defines the quotient operator and characterizes some useful properties, Section 2.2 establishes an SRG product theorem and apply it to the quotient operator, and Section 2.3 proves Theorem 2.1.

2.1 Quotient operator

For :ℋ⇉ℋ:absent⇉ℋℋ{\varbbA}\colon{\mathcal{H}}\rightrightarrows{\mathcal{H}}: caligraphic_H ⇉ caligraphic_H and :ℋ⇉ℋ:absent⇉ℋℋ{\varbbB}\colon{\mathcal{H}}\rightrightarrows{\mathcal{H}}: caligraphic_H ⇉ caligraphic_H, define the quotient operator of over as

=/=.−1\frac{{\varbbA}}{{\varbbB}}={\varbbA}/{\varbbB}={\varbbA}{}^{-1}.divide start_ARG end_ARG start_ARG end_ARG = / = start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT .

Correspondingly, for a class of operators 𝒜𝒜{\mathcal{A}}caligraphic_A, define

𝒜=𝒜/=𝒜.−1\frac{{\mathcal{A}}}{{\varbbB}}={\mathcal{A}}/{\varbbB}={\mathcal{A}}{}^{-1}.divide start_ARG caligraphic_A end_ARG start_ARG end_ARG = caligraphic_A / = caligraphic_A start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT .

For a single-valued operator :ℋ⇉ℋ:absent⇉ℋℋ{\varbbA}\colon{\mathcal{H}}\rightrightarrows{\mathcal{H}}: caligraphic_H ⇉ caligraphic_H, define the selection of with respect to distinct x𝑥xitalic_x, y∈ℋ𝑦ℋy\in{\mathcal{H}}italic_y ∈ caligraphic_H as

=x,y{{(x,x),(y,y)}if ⁢x,y∈dom,{(x,x)}if ⁢x∈dom,y∉dom,{(y,y)}if ⁢x∉dom,y∈dom,∅otherwise.{}_{x,y}=\begin{cases}\{(x,{\varbbA}x),(y,{\varbbA}y)\}&\text{if }x,y\in% \mathrm{dom}\,{\varbbA},\\ \{(x,{\varbbA}x)\}&\text{if }x\in\mathrm{dom}\,{\varbbA},y\notin\mathrm{dom}\,% {\varbbA},\\ \{(y,{\varbbA}y)\}&\text{if }x\notin\mathrm{dom}\,{\varbbA},y\in\mathrm{dom}\,% {\varbbA},\\ \emptyset&\text{otherwise}.\end{cases}start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_y end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT = { start_ROW start_CELL { ( italic_x , italic_x ) , ( italic_y , italic_y ) } end_CELL start_CELL if italic_x , italic_y ∈ roman_dom , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL { ( italic_x , italic_x ) } end_CELL start_CELL if italic_x ∈ roman_dom , italic_y ∉ roman_dom , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL { ( italic_y , italic_y ) } end_CELL start_CELL if italic_x ∉ roman_dom , italic_y ∈ roman_dom , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL ∅ end_CELL start_CELL otherwise . end_CELL end_ROW

We clarify that =x,y/x,y{}_{x,y}={\varbbA}/{}_{x,y}start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_y end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT = / start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_y end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT.

We point out some immediate consequences. Let :ℋ⇉ℋ:absent⇉ℋℋ{\varbbA}\colon{\mathcal{H}}\rightrightarrows{\mathcal{H}}: caligraphic_H ⇉ caligraphic_H and :ℋ⇉ℋ:absent⇉ℋℋ{\varbbB}\colon{\mathcal{H}}\rightrightarrows{\mathcal{H}}: caligraphic_H ⇉ caligraphic_H be single-valued operators. Then, for distinct x𝑥xitalic_x, y∈ℋ𝑦ℋy\in{\mathcal{H}}italic_y ∈ caligraphic_H,

(1) 𝒢(/)x,y\displaystyle{\mathcal{G}}\left({\varbbA}/{}_{x,y}\right)caligraphic_G ( / start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_y end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT ) ={∥x−y∥∥x−y∥⁢exp⁡[±i⁢∠⁢(x−y,x−y)]if ⁢x≠y,∞if ⁢x≠y,x=y,∅otherwise.absentcasesdelimited-∥∥𝑥𝑦delimited-∥∥𝑥𝑦plus-or-minus𝑖∠𝑥𝑦𝑥𝑦if 𝑥𝑦formulae-sequenceif 𝑥𝑦𝑥𝑦otherwise.\displaystyle=\begin{cases}\frac{\lVert{\varbbA}x-{\varbbA}y\rVert}{\lVert{% \varbbB}x-{\varbbB}y\rVert}\exp[\pm i\angle({\varbbA}x-{\varbbA}y,{\varbbB}x-{% \varbbB}y)]&\text{if }{\varbbB}x\neq{\varbbB}y,\\ \infty&\text{if }{\varbbA}x\neq{\varbbA}y,{\varbbB}x={\varbbB}y,\\ \emptyset&\text{otherwise.}\end{cases}= { start_ROW start_CELL divide start_ARG ∥ italic_x - italic_y ∥ end_ARG start_ARG ∥ italic_x - italic_y ∥ end_ARG roman_exp [ ± italic_i ∠ ( italic_x - italic_y , italic_x - italic_y ) ] end_CELL start_CELL if italic_x ≠ italic_y , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL ∞ end_CELL start_CELL if italic_x ≠ italic_y , italic_x = italic_y , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL ∅ end_CELL start_CELL otherwise. end_CELL end_ROW

If :ℋ⇉ℋ:absent⇉ℋℋ{\varbbA}\colon{\mathcal{H}}\rightrightarrows{\mathcal{H}}: caligraphic_H ⇉ caligraphic_H is a single-valued operator, then

(2) ⋃x,y∈ℋx≠y𝒢(/)x,y=𝒢().\bigcup_{\begin{subarray}{c}x,y\in{\mathcal{H}}\\ x\neq y\end{subarray}}{\mathcal{G}}\left({\varbbA}/{}_{x,y}\right)={\mathcal{G% }}\left({\varbbA}\right).⋃ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL italic_x , italic_y ∈ caligraphic_H end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_x ≠ italic_y end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_G ( / start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_y end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT ) = caligraphic_G ( ) .

Informally, the following lemma says that for SRG-full classes, we can recover the entire SRG from a single x,y𝑥𝑦x,yitalic_x , italic_y pair.

Lemma 2.6.

Let ℋℋ{\mathcal{H}}caligraphic_H be a real Hilbert space with dimℋ≥2dimensionℋ2\dim{\mathcal{H}}\geq 2roman_dim caligraphic_H ≥ 2. For any distinct x,y∈ℋ𝑥𝑦ℋx,y\in{\mathcal{H}}italic_x , italic_y ∈ caligraphic_H and an SRG-full class 𝒜𝒜{\mathcal{A}}caligraphic_A consisting of single-valued operators,

𝒢(𝒜/)x,y=𝒢(𝒜).{\mathcal{G}}\left({\mathcal{A}}/{}_{x,y}\right)={\mathcal{G}}\left({\mathcal{% A}}\right).caligraphic_G ( caligraphic_A / start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_y end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT ) = caligraphic_G ( caligraphic_A ) .

Proof 2.7.

For any :ℋ⇉ℋ:absent⇉ℋℋ{\varbbA}\colon{\mathcal{H}}\rightrightarrows{\mathcal{H}}: caligraphic_H ⇉ caligraphic_H where ∈𝒜absent𝒜{\varbbA}\in{\mathcal{A}}∈ caligraphic_A , we have 𝒢(/)x,y⊆𝒢(){\mathcal{G}}\left({\varbbA}/{}_{x,y}\right)\subseteq{\mathcal{G}}\left({% \varbbA}\right)caligraphic_G ( / start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_y end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT ) ⊆ caligraphic_G ( ) from (2), and 𝒢(𝒜/)x,y⊆𝒢(𝒜){\mathcal{G}}\left({\mathcal{A}}/{}_{x,y}\right)\subseteq{\mathcal{G}}\left({% \mathcal{A}}\right)caligraphic_G ( caligraphic_A / start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_y end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT ) ⊆ caligraphic_G ( caligraphic_A ).

We now prove 𝒢(𝒜)⊆𝒢(𝒜/)x,y{\mathcal{G}}\left({\mathcal{A}}\right)\subseteq{\mathcal{G}}\left({\mathcal{A% }}/{}_{x,y}\right)caligraphic_G ( caligraphic_A ) ⊆ caligraphic_G ( caligraphic_A / start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_y end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT ). Let zA∈𝒢⁢(𝒜)subscript𝑧𝐴𝒢𝒜z_{A}\in{\mathcal{G}}\left({\mathcal{A}}\right)italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_G ( caligraphic_A ) with Im⁡zA≥0Imsubscript𝑧𝐴0\operatorname{Im}z_{A}\geq 0roman_Im italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ 0. Then, there exist u,v∈ℋ𝑢𝑣ℋu,v\in{\mathcal{H}}italic_u , italic_v ∈ caligraphic_H such that

zA=∥u−v∥∥x−y∥⁢exp⁡[i⁢∠⁢(u−v,x−y)],subscript𝑧𝐴delimited-∥∥𝑢𝑣delimited-∥∥𝑥𝑦𝑖∠𝑢𝑣𝑥𝑦z_{A}=\frac{\lVert u-v\rVert}{\lVert x-y\rVert}\exp[i\angle(u-v,x-y)],italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG ∥ italic_u - italic_v ∥ end_ARG start_ARG ∥ italic_x - italic_y ∥ end_ARG roman_exp [ italic_i ∠ ( italic_u - italic_v , italic_x - italic_y ) ] ,

since dimℋ≥2dimensionℋ2\dim{\mathcal{H}}\geq 2roman_dim caligraphic_H ≥ 2. By Fact 5, there exists ∈𝒜absent𝒜{\varbbA}\in{\mathcal{A}}∈ caligraphic_A such that :ℋ⇉ℋ:absent⇉ℋℋ{\varbbA}\colon{\mathcal{H}}\rightrightarrows{\mathcal{H}}: caligraphic_H ⇉ caligraphic_H and x=u𝑥𝑢{\varbbA}x=uitalic_x = italic_u, y=v𝑦𝑣{\varbbA}y=vitalic_y = italic_v. Hence, zA∈𝒢(/)x,y⊆𝒢(𝒜/)x,yz_{A}\in{\mathcal{G}}\left({\varbbA}/{}_{x,y}\right)\subseteq{\mathcal{G}}% \left({\mathcal{A}}/{}_{x,y}\right)italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_G ( / start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_y end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT ) ⊆ caligraphic_G ( caligraphic_A / start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_y end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT ). Since SRGs are symmetric about the real axis, we can apply the same reasoning for zA∈𝒢⁢(𝒜)subscript𝑧𝐴𝒢𝒜z_{A}\in{\mathcal{G}}\left({\mathcal{A}}\right)italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_G ( caligraphic_A ) with Im⁡zA<0Imsubscript𝑧𝐴0\operatorname{Im}z_{A}<0roman_Im italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 0. Hence, 𝒢(𝒜)⊆𝒢(𝒜/)x,y{\mathcal{G}}\left({\mathcal{A}}\right)\subseteq{\mathcal{G}}\left({\mathcal{A% }}/{}_{x,y}\right)caligraphic_G ( caligraphic_A ) ⊆ caligraphic_G ( caligraphic_A / start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_y end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT ), and we conclude the proof.

We now introduce some rules of calculus with the quotient operators.

Lemma 2.8.

(Calculus of quotient operators) Let , , , :ℋ⇉ℋ:absent⇉ℋℋ{\varbbD}\colon{\mathcal{H}}\rightrightarrows{\mathcal{H}}: caligraphic_H ⇉ caligraphic_H be single-valued operators and distinct x𝑥xitalic_x, y∈ℋ𝑦ℋy\in{\mathcal{H}}italic_y ∈ caligraphic_H. Then the following identities hold:

(3) 𝒢(/)x,y\displaystyle{\mathcal{G}}\left({\varbbA}/{}_{x,y}\right)caligraphic_G ( / start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_y end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT ) =𝒢(/)x,y−1\displaystyle={\mathcal{G}}\left({\varbbB}/{}_{x,y}\right)^{-1}= caligraphic_G ( / start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_y end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT
(4) (+t)/x,y\displaystyle\left({{\varbbA}+t{\varbbB}}\right)/{}_{x,y}( + italic_t ) / start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_y end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT =/+x,yt\displaystyle={\varbbA}/{}_{x,y}+t{\varbbI}= / start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_y end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT + italic_t (t∈ℝ)𝑡ℝ\displaystyle(t\in\mathbb{R})( italic_t ∈ blackboard_R )
(5) (t)/x,y\displaystyle\left({t{\varbbA}}\right)/{}_{x,y}( italic_t ) / start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_y end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT =t(/)x,y\displaystyle=t\left({{\varbbA}/{}_{x,y}}\right)= italic_t ( / start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_y end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT ) (t∈ℝ)𝑡ℝ\displaystyle(t\in\mathbb{R})( italic_t ∈ blackboard_R )
(6) |𝒢(/)x,y|\displaystyle\lvert{\mathcal{G}}\left({\varbbA}/{}_{x,y}\right)\rvert| caligraphic_G ( / start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_y end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT ) | =|𝒢(/)x,y||𝒢(/)x,y|\displaystyle=\lvert{\mathcal{G}}\left({\varbbA}/{}_{x,y}\right)\rvert\lvert{% \mathcal{G}}\left({\varbbB}/{}_{x,y}\right)\rvert= | caligraphic_G ( / start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_y end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT ) | | caligraphic_G ( / start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_y end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT ) | (x≠y,x≠y)formulae-sequence𝑥𝑦𝑥𝑦\displaystyle({\varbbB}x\neq{\varbbB}y,{\varbbC}x\neq{\varbbC}y)( italic_x ≠ italic_y , italic_x ≠ italic_y )
(7) 𝒢((+)/)x,y\displaystyle{\mathcal{G}}\left(({\varbbA}+{\varbbD})/{}_{x,y}\right)caligraphic_G ( ( + ) / start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_y end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT ) =𝒢(/)x,y\displaystyle={\mathcal{G}}\left({\varbbA}/{}_{x,y}\right)= caligraphic_G ( / start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_y end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT ) (x=y).𝑥𝑦\displaystyle({\varbbD}x={\varbbD}y).( italic_x = italic_y ) .

Proof 2.9.

In our proofs of (3), (4), and (5), we assume x,y∈dom∩dom𝑥𝑦domdomx,y\in\mathrm{dom}\,{\varbbA}\cap\mathrm{dom}\,{\varbbB}italic_x , italic_y ∈ roman_dom ∩ roman_dom, as otherwise the statements are straightforwardly true due to (1). We assume similar conditions for (7) regarding domains of and .

(3) If x≠y𝑥𝑦{\varbbA}x\neq{\varbbA}yitalic_x ≠ italic_y and x≠y𝑥𝑦{\varbbB}x\neq{\varbbB}yitalic_x ≠ italic_y,

𝒢(/)x,y\displaystyle{\mathcal{G}}\left({\varbbA}/{}_{x,y}\right)caligraphic_G ( / start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_y end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT ) =∥x−y∥∥x−y∥⁢exp⁡[±i⁢∠⁢(x−y,x−y)]absentdelimited-∥∥𝑥𝑦delimited-∥∥𝑥𝑦plus-or-minus𝑖∠𝑥𝑦𝑥𝑦\displaystyle=\frac{\lVert{\varbbA}x-{\varbbA}y\rVert}{\lVert{\varbbB}x-{% \varbbB}y\rVert}\exp[\pm i\angle({\varbbA}x-{\varbbA}y,{\varbbB}x-{\varbbB}y)]= divide start_ARG ∥ italic_x - italic_y ∥ end_ARG start_ARG ∥ italic_x - italic_y ∥ end_ARG roman_exp [ ± italic_i ∠ ( italic_x - italic_y , italic_x - italic_y ) ]
=(∥x−y∥∥x−y∥⁢exp⁡[±i⁢∠⁢(x−y,x−y)])−1absentsuperscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑥𝑦delimited-∥∥𝑥𝑦plus-or-minus𝑖∠𝑥𝑦𝑥𝑦1\displaystyle=\bigg{(}\frac{\lVert{\varbbB}x-{\varbbB}y\rVert}{\lVert{\varbbA}% x-{\varbbA}y\rVert}\exp[\pm i\angle({\varbbA}x-{\varbbA}y,{\varbbB}x-{\varbbB}% y)]\bigg{)}^{-1}= ( divide start_ARG ∥ italic_x - italic_y ∥ end_ARG start_ARG ∥ italic_x - italic_y ∥ end_ARG roman_exp [ ± italic_i ∠ ( italic_x - italic_y , italic_x - italic_y ) ] ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT
=𝒢(/)x,y−1.\displaystyle={\mathcal{G}}\left({\varbbB}/{}_{x,y}\right)^{-1}.= caligraphic_G ( / start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_y end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

If x=y𝑥𝑦{\varbbA}x={\varbbA}yitalic_x = italic_y and x≠y𝑥𝑦{\varbbB}x\neq{\varbbB}yitalic_x ≠ italic_y, then 𝒢(/)x,y=0=∞−1=𝒢(/)x,y−1{\mathcal{G}}\left({\varbbA}/{}_{x,y}\right)=0=\infty^{-1}={\mathcal{G}}\left(% {\varbbB}/{}_{x,y}\right)^{-1}caligraphic_G ( / start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_y end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT ) = 0 = ∞ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = caligraphic_G ( / start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_y end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.
If x≠y𝑥𝑦{\varbbA}x\neq{\varbbA}yitalic_x ≠ italic_y and x=y𝑥𝑦{\varbbB}x={\varbbB}yitalic_x = italic_y, then 𝒢(/)x,y=∞=0−1=𝒢(/)x,y−1{\mathcal{G}}\left({\varbbA}/{}_{x,y}\right)=\infty=0^{-1}={\mathcal{G}}\left(% {\varbbB}/{}_{x,y}\right)^{-1}caligraphic_G ( / start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_y end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT ) = ∞ = 0 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = caligraphic_G ( / start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_y end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

(4) Both sides evaluate to x+t⁢x𝑥𝑡𝑥{\varbbA}x+t{\varbbB}xitalic_x + italic_t italic_x and y+t⁢y𝑦𝑡𝑦{\varbbA}y+t{\varbbB}yitalic_y + italic_t italic_y for inputs x𝑥{\varbbB}xitalic_x and y𝑦{\varbbB}yitalic_y, respectively. Otherwise, both sides evaluate to ∅\emptyset∅.

(5) This follows immediately from our operator notation.

(6) This follows from

|𝒢(/)x,y|\displaystyle\lvert{\mathcal{G}}\left({\varbbA}/{}_{x,y}\right)\rvert| caligraphic_G ( / start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_y end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT ) | =∥x−y∥∥x−y∥absentdelimited-∥∥𝑥𝑦delimited-∥∥𝑥𝑦\displaystyle=\frac{\lVert{\varbbA}x-{\varbbA}y\rVert}{\lVert{\varbbC}x-{% \varbbC}y\rVert}= divide start_ARG ∥ italic_x - italic_y ∥ end_ARG start_ARG ∥ italic_x - italic_y ∥ end_ARG
=∥x−y∥∥x−y∥⁢∥x−y∥∥x−y∥absentdelimited-∥∥𝑥𝑦delimited-∥∥𝑥𝑦delimited-∥∥𝑥𝑦delimited-∥∥𝑥𝑦\displaystyle=\frac{\lVert{\varbbA}x-{\varbbA}y\rVert}{\lVert{\varbbB}x-{% \varbbB}y\rVert}\frac{\lVert{\varbbB}x-{\varbbB}y\rVert}{\lVert{\varbbC}x-{% \varbbC}y\rVert}= divide start_ARG ∥ italic_x - italic_y ∥ end_ARG start_ARG ∥ italic_x - italic_y ∥ end_ARG divide start_ARG ∥ italic_x - italic_y ∥ end_ARG start_ARG ∥ italic_x - italic_y ∥ end_ARG
=|𝒢(/)x,y||𝒢(/)x,y|.\displaystyle=\lvert{\mathcal{G}}\left({\varbbA}/{}_{x,y}\right)\rvert\lvert{% \mathcal{G}}\left({\varbbB}/{}_{x,y}\right)\rvert.= | caligraphic_G ( / start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_y end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT ) | | caligraphic_G ( / start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_y end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT ) | .

(7) Observe that

(+)⁢x−(+)⁢y=x−y,𝑥𝑦𝑥𝑦({\varbbA}+{\varbbD})x-({\varbbA}+{\varbbD})y={\varbbA}x-{\varbbA}y,( + ) italic_x - ( + ) italic_y = italic_x - italic_y ,

which, together with (1), gives the desired result.

2.2 SRG product theorem

We first establish a product theorem for SRGs, which is of independent interest. This product theorem differs from [38, Theorem 7] in that one of operands is a single fixed operator, rather than an operator class. We then apply it to the quotient operator.

Theorem 2.10 (SRG product theorem).

Let ℋℋ{\mathcal{H}}caligraphic_H be a real Hilbert space with dim⁢ℋ≥2dimℋ2\textrm{dim}\,{\mathcal{H}}\geq 2dim caligraphic_H ≥ 2 and :ℋ⇉ℋ:absent⇉ℋℋ{\varbbB}\colon{\mathcal{H}}\rightrightarrows{\mathcal{H}}: caligraphic_H ⇉ caligraphic_H be a single-valued operator. Let 𝒜𝒜{\mathcal{A}}caligraphic_A be a SRG-full class of single-valued operators satisfying an arc property, and assume 𝒢⁢(𝒜)≠∅𝒢𝒜{\mathcal{G}}\left({\mathcal{A}}\right)\neq\emptysetcaligraphic_G ( caligraphic_A ) ≠ ∅. Then,

𝒢⁢(𝒜)=𝒢⁢(𝒜)⁢𝒢⁢().𝒢𝒜𝒢𝒜𝒢{\mathcal{G}}\left({\mathcal{A}}{\varbbB}\right)={\mathcal{G}}\left({\mathcal{% A}}\right){\mathcal{G}}\left({\varbbB}\right).caligraphic_G ( caligraphic_A ) = caligraphic_G ( caligraphic_A ) caligraphic_G ( ) .

(Note, ∞∉𝒢⁢(𝒜)𝒢𝒜\infty\notin{\mathcal{G}}({\mathcal{A}})∞ ∉ caligraphic_G ( caligraphic_A ) since operators in 𝒜𝒜{\mathcal{A}}caligraphic_A are single-valued.)

Proof 2.11.

We first show 𝒢⁢(𝒜)⁢𝒢⁢()⊆𝒢⁢(𝒜)𝒢𝒜𝒢𝒢𝒜{\mathcal{G}}\left({\mathcal{A}}\right){\mathcal{G}}\left({\varbbB}\right)% \subseteq{\mathcal{G}}\left({\mathcal{A}}{\varbbB}\right)caligraphic_G ( caligraphic_A ) caligraphic_G ( ) ⊆ caligraphic_G ( caligraphic_A ). Let zA∈𝒢⁢(𝒜)subscript𝑧𝐴𝒢𝒜z_{A}\in{\mathcal{G}}\left({\mathcal{A}}\right)italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_G ( caligraphic_A ) and zB∈𝒢⁢()subscript𝑧𝐵𝒢z_{B}\in{\mathcal{G}}\left({\varbbB}\right)italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_G ( ). If zB=0subscript𝑧𝐵0z_{B}=0italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0, there exists distinct x,y∈ℋ𝑥𝑦ℋx,y\in{\mathcal{H}}italic_x , italic_y ∈ caligraphic_H such that x=y𝑥𝑦{\varbbB}x={\varbbB}yitalic_x = italic_y. Take ={(x,0)}absent𝑥0{\varbbA}=\{({\varbbB}x,0)\}= { ( italic_x , 0 ) }. Then ∈𝒜absent𝒜{\varbbA}\in{\mathcal{A}}∈ caligraphic_A by Fact 6. This gives

zA⁢zB=0=∥x−y∥∥x−y∥⁢exp⁡[i⁢∠⁢(x−y,x−y)]∈𝒢⁢().subscript𝑧𝐴subscript𝑧𝐵0delimited-∥∥𝑥𝑦delimited-∥∥𝑥𝑦𝑖∠𝑥𝑦𝑥𝑦𝒢z_{A}z_{B}=0=\frac{\lVert{\varbbA}{\varbbB}x-{\varbbA}{\varbbB}y\rVert}{\lVert x% -y\rVert}\exp[i\angle({\varbbA}{\varbbB}x-{\varbbA}{\varbbB}y,x-y)]\in{% \mathcal{G}}\left({\varbbA}{\varbbB}\right).italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 = divide start_ARG ∥ italic_x - italic_y ∥ end_ARG start_ARG ∥ italic_x - italic_y ∥ end_ARG roman_exp [ italic_i ∠ ( italic_x - italic_y , italic_x - italic_y ) ] ∈ caligraphic_G ( ) .

Otherwise, assume zB≠0subscript𝑧𝐵0z_{B}\neq 0italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≠ 0. Then there exists distinct x,y∈ℋ𝑥𝑦ℋx,y\in{\mathcal{H}}italic_x , italic_y ∈ caligraphic_H such that x≠y𝑥𝑦{\varbbB}x\neq{\varbbB}yitalic_x ≠ italic_y and

zB∈‖x−y‖‖x−y‖⁢exp⁡[±i⁢∠⁢(x−y,x−y)].subscript𝑧𝐵norm𝑥𝑦norm𝑥𝑦plus-or-minus𝑖∠𝑥𝑦𝑥𝑦z_{B}\in\frac{\|{\varbbB}x-{\varbbB}y\|}{\|x-y\|}\exp\left[\pm i\angle({% \varbbB}x-{\varbbB}y,x-y)\right].italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ divide start_ARG ∥ italic_x - italic_y ∥ end_ARG start_ARG ∥ italic_x - italic_y ∥ end_ARG roman_exp [ ± italic_i ∠ ( italic_x - italic_y , italic_x - italic_y ) ] .

There also exists orthonormal vectors {e1,e2}⊂ℋsubscript𝑒1subscript𝑒2ℋ\{e_{1},e_{2}\}\subset{\mathcal{H}}{ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } ⊂ caligraphic_H such that

e1subscript𝑒1\displaystyle e_{1}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =(x−y)/∥x−y∥absent𝑥𝑦delimited-∥∥𝑥𝑦\displaystyle=(x-y)/\lVert x-y\rVert= ( italic_x - italic_y ) / ∥ italic_x - italic_y ∥

u𝑢\displaystyle uitalic_u =∥x−y∥⁢((Re⁡(zA⁢zB))⁢e1+(Im⁡(zA⁢zB))⁢e2)absentdelimited-∥∥𝑥𝑦Resubscript𝑧𝐴subscript𝑧𝐵subscript𝑒1Imsubscript𝑧𝐴subscript𝑧𝐵subscript𝑒2\displaystyle=\lVert x-y\rVert((\operatorname{Re}(z_{A}z_{B}))e_{1}+(% \operatorname{Im}(z_{A}z_{B}))e_{2})= ∥ italic_x - italic_y ∥ ( ( roman_Re ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ( roman_Im ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
v𝑣\displaystyle vitalic_v =0.absent0\displaystyle=0.= 0 .

and
